And I know you've outlined some downside risk to export coal. I was just wondering what your thinking is on the domestic side from the utility stockpile? And also what level do you think natural gas will be?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, obviously, we don't foresee natural gas rebounding significant than from where it is today. And as a result, most likely, for the rest of the year, we expect our coal plants that we serve to be dispatched last. We're seeing obviously excess s
componenttext: Yes. I mean, obviously, we don't foresee natural gas rebounding significant than from where it is today. And as a result, most likely, for the rest of the year, we expect our coal plants that we serve to be dispatched last. We're seeing obviously excess stockpiles right now. If we look at where we are, we're probably in the 110s or so in terms of the south, and more in the 80 range in the northern part of our network, which should probably be in the 55 to 70 range. So as we think about that 19 million of domestic coal, it really breaks down into 2 components. One is the utility coal, which is about 14 million tons, and steel and industrial about 5 million tons to make up that 19 million. We did about 13.6 million here in the fourth quarter. And so we're essentially saying we will continue that run rate. And we expect some destocking to occur over the year, but how much really will be dependent on the weather since we now are dispatched last. We're essentially peakers [ph], so we're very much weather dependent. If you have favorable weather conditions from a railroad perspective or utility perspective, then you can see a more significant destocking. If you have continued this sort of weather pattern we saw in the fourth quarter, where heating degree days were actually off by about 25% to 30% off normal, then that will be much more challenging. But hopefully, we'll -- we won't see that and we will see some destocking occur within the guidance that we provided.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the other one related to the gas that I was -- the coal and gas switching. Difficult to tell, but from a structural perspective, are there any pockets of the network, perhaps in the north near the Marcellus Shale, where you would expect to see some mo
componenttext: And the other one related to the gas that I was -- the coal and gas switching. Difficult to tell, but from a structural perspective, are there any pockets of the network, perhaps in the north near the Marcellus Shale, where you would expect to see some more gas plants being built that could perhaps provide a little bit of incremental pressure on the rest of the network?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think that all the switching that can occur already occurred back in March or April of last year. What we have seen is, in some instances, we are seeing some of the coal burners actually now burning some natural gas in conjunction to coal firing wit
componenttext: No. I think that all the switching that can occur already occurred back in March or April of last year. What we have seen is, in some instances, we are seeing some of the coal burners actually now burning some natural gas in conjunction to coal firing with natural gas that has had a little bit of an incremental additional negative impact on us, but all the switching that can occur has already occurred. And we are being dispatched last or we -- the utilities that we serve, are being dispatched last.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will be coming from Chris Wetherbee from Citi.
componenttext: Our next question will be coming from Chris Wetherbee from Citi.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask you about the coal network and sort of where you are in terms of your potential structural changes that you're doing, and you set some actions in the fourth quarter. And I guess I'm curious kind of what else can be done as you move forward
componenttext: I wanted to ask you about the coal network and sort of where you are in terms of your potential structural changes that you're doing, and you set some actions in the fourth quarter. And I guess I'm curious kind of what else can be done as you move forward to 2016 given the outlook. And then maybe how that ties into productivity and benefit that you're getting with the great run rate in the fourth quarter? I'm kind of curious what could potentially give us upside to that 200 number in 2016.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, Chris, good morning. This is Cindy. As far as structural costs, you did mention the actions that we took in the fourth quarter. And as I talked in our third quarter release, everything is on the table, not just in our coal network but also in our br
componenttext: Okay, Chris, good morning. This is Cindy. As far as structural costs, you did mention the actions that we took in the fourth quarter. And as I talked in our third quarter release, everything is on the table, not just in our coal network but also in our broader footprint and our opportunities that we're looking for to drive density, maximize asset utilization and drive out costs. Facilities are still -- maybe some opportunities there. I think line segments will take a little bit more time. They involve customers and other constituencies there that make those a little bit more longer term, but we are looking at all of these. And as we find opportunities and make announcements, we'll obviously share that publicly. But we have not given up on continuing to find ways to make our footprint much more consistent with the demand that is put on. And you asked another question about productivity. Can I ask you to repeat that?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I just wanted to get a sense on maybe how the coal network's ties into the productivity, the $200 million of productivity. And then given the run rate you had in the fourth quarter, which was a bit above that level, sort of how do you think about ma
componenttext: Sure. I just wanted to get a sense on maybe how the coal network's ties into the productivity, the $200 million of productivity. And then given the run rate you had in the fourth quarter, which was a bit above that level, sort of how do you think about maybe potential upside? Is there more that you can see from productivity in 2016?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: So thinking about productivity, we said we're going to be able to achieve $200 million of productivity savings in addition to the rightsizing actions that we're taking. I think when you look at the $200 million of productivity, about $100 million is alrea
componenttext: So thinking about productivity, we said we're going to be able to achieve $200 million of productivity savings in addition to the rightsizing actions that we're taking. I think when you look at the $200 million of productivity, about $100 million is already -- those initiatives have already been completed, and we feel really good about that. And the other initiatives are in flight and we feel good about that. There isn't necessarily tie or non-tie to the coal network. It's all -- it's broad-based and it's everywhere. And as far as the rightsizing initiatives -- just I'll comment on that even it's not necessarily your question, it might be something you're thinking about. The way to think about that is the fourth quarter -- the past is prologue. We will be relentless on driving out costs that are volume-related as we see demand go down, and then in the opposite, as Michael mentioned, as we see opportunities where demand comes back, we will be able to bring back those resources.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will be coming from Tom Wadewitz from UBS.
componenttext: Our next question will be coming from Tom Wadewitz from UBS.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask you, I guess, that -- how maybe train starts, just a brief follow on that, and then maybe on pricing. I don't know if you want to give me [indiscernible], but the train -- Cindy, just a quick one. How much were train starts down in the fou
componenttext: I wanted to ask you, I guess, that -- how maybe train starts, just a brief follow on that, and then maybe on pricing. I don't know if you want to give me [indiscernible], but the train -- Cindy, just a quick one. How much were train starts down in the fourth quarter and maybe what that could be in 2016? And then on the pricing. I don't know if you answered this when Ken was on earlier. But did you give us a sense of what core price or same-store price might be in 2016? Or is that something that you can comment on?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me just take the pricing question because that's probably the simplest one. We really don't forecast pricing. We're going to provide each and every quarter where we come out. The key thing is that you should know that we're always -- we're always focu
componenttext: Let me just take the pricing question because that's probably the simplest one. We really don't forecast pricing. We're going to provide each and every quarter where we come out. The key thing is that you should know that we're always -- we're always focused on pricing, making sure we get the appropriate value so we continue to reinvest in our business. As we think about our pricing right now, we have an incredibly strong service product. It's improved significantly over the last 6 months as we now have the resources in place. There's a lot of contracts that we still haven't been able to touch, and it's really the step function change that occurred in early 2014. The contract side on the trucking side is still holding up okay even though the spot market is very soft. And the key thing for our team is to continue to sell through this downcycle and make sure we provide value to our customers by selling a longer-term commitment in terms of making sure they have access to our network and so that we work through this downcycle right now and sell for the long term.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Tom, on starts, I would say probably about 1,000 starts per week that are scheduled starts will be -- are out and, obviously, starts will come out that are volume-related more on the new train side.
componenttext: And Tom, on starts, I would say probably about 1,000 starts per week that are scheduled starts will be -- are out and, obviously, starts will come out that are volume-related more on the new train side.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: What -- can you give that as a percentage change, like how much -- what percent train starts were down maybe in the fourth quarter and what they might be in '16?
componenttext: What -- can you give that as a percentage change, like how much -- what percent train starts were down maybe in the fourth quarter and what they might be in '16?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't have a percentage right in front of me there, Tom, but I can tell you that our train length initiatives have obviously driven a lot of this opportunity.
componenttext: I don't have a percentage right in front of me there, Tom, but I can tell you that our train length initiatives have obviously driven a lot of this opportunity.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: What, from the beginning of the year, Cindy, about 15%?
componenttext: What, from the beginning of the year, Cindy, about 15%?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: For the total year of 2015, they're up 8% from '14 versus '15. And in the fourth quarter, they're up 14% from the fourth quarter of '14 to the fourth quarter of '15.
componenttext: For the total year of 2015, they're up 8% from '14 versus '15. And in the fourth quarter, they're up 14% from the fourth quarter of '14 to the fourth quarter of '15.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: The declines year-over-year in train starts, you're saying?
componenttext: The declines year-over-year in train starts, you're saying?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm saying train lengths in terms of...
componenttext: I'm saying train lengths in terms of...

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Train lengths, gain in train lengths. Okay, sorry.
componenttext: Train lengths, gain in train lengths. Okay, sorry.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Which then translates into 1,000 starts per week, which we talked about. So that gives you a percentage and gives you some sort of sense of where we stand on a percentage basis.
componenttext: Which then translates into 1,000 starts per week, which we talked about. So that gives you a percentage and gives you some sort of sense of where we stand on a percentage basis.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, yes. I mean, they're strong gains, especially given the volume headwinds.
componenttext: Okay, yes. I mean, they're strong gains, especially given the volume headwinds.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will be coming from Allison Landry from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question will be coming from Allison Landry from Crédit Suisse.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: So given all the debate surrounding M&A and both of the eastern rails talking about getting to a 65 OR over the next few years and some others saying 60 should be the bogey. First, could you help to bookend the time frame for when you think you can achiev
componenttext: So given all the debate surrounding M&A and both of the eastern rails talking about getting to a 65 OR over the next few years and some others saying 60 should be the bogey. First, could you help to bookend the time frame for when you think you can achieve this 65 and what, if any, your plan is from a longer-term perspective to close the gap with your peers to ultimately achieve a 60 OR?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Allison, it's Frank. Obviously, we can't comment on what other railroads are projecting into the future. But the challenging environment that we see in 2016 does not in any way diminish our confidence and the ability to deliver the mid-60s operating ratio
componenttext: Allison, it's Frank. Obviously, we can't comment on what other railroads are projecting into the future. But the challenging environment that we see in 2016 does not in any way diminish our confidence and the ability to deliver the mid-60s operating ratio longer term that we have guided you toward in the past and again today. As you know, we've got an awfully good network, a world-class network in the east, and you've seen our success over time both in terms of delivering margin improvement and the cost take-out that Cindy referenced, in addition to the operating side on the G&A side. So the efforts that we're taking now, especially in an improving environment in the future, is going to help us improve margins in a meaningful basis as that improves. But as we sit here today, based on the forward view of 2016, it just seems a little inappropriate for us to guide on a specific time frame right now.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and I guess just sort of a clarification question. Do you think that at some point in the future, is there anything structural that would prevent CSX from achieving a 60 OR?
componenttext: Okay, and I guess just sort of a clarification question. Do you think that at some point in the future, is there anything structural that would prevent CSX from achieving a 60 OR?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: We don't see anything structural that would impede us from getting to the mid-60s and through the mid-60s. Obviously, it's going to depend on a whole host of things. And again, as Michael said, the crystal ball is a little cloudy in '16. And obviously, as
componenttext: We don't see anything structural that would impede us from getting to the mid-60s and through the mid-60s. Obviously, it's going to depend on a whole host of things. And again, as Michael said, the crystal ball is a little cloudy in '16. And obviously, as that clarity improves, we'll be able to give you more guidance around that.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question will be coming from Rob Salmon from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: The next question will be coming from Rob Salmon from Deutsche Bank.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fred, if I could take it back to the intermodal discussion, you'd alluded to some international contract losses that have happened kind of through the year. In the guidance, it's kind of implying roughly a 70,000 unit sequential decline, which is much mor
componenttext: Fred, if I could take it back to the intermodal discussion, you'd alluded to some international contract losses that have happened kind of through the year. In the guidance, it's kind of implying roughly a 70,000 unit sequential decline, which is much more than normal we would see in kind of Q1 versus Q4. Was there an incremental contract loss in the fourth quarter or are you guys contemplating additional inventory destocking that we should be thinking about in the first quarter?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure which guidance you are looking at. I guess we have the fact that we have the intermodal business in the flat. Is that what you're referring to?
componenttext: I'm not sure which guidance you are looking at. I guess we have the fact that we have the intermodal business in the flat. Is that what you're referring to?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's, in aggregate, intermodal carloads being roughly flat. And so I've just kind of taken a flattish number and comparing that sequentially to the fourth quarter of carloads that we saw. And just curious what's driving the worse-than-normal drop-off
componenttext: Yes, it's, in aggregate, intermodal carloads being roughly flat. And so I've just kind of taken a flattish number and comparing that sequentially to the fourth quarter of carloads that we saw. And just curious what's driving the worse-than-normal drop-off in Q1, whether it's an incremental international loss or some inventory destocking that you got contemplated or something you're hearing from customers?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sequentially, fourth quarter to first quarter is a very different story, obviously, with the peak that we're seeing in the fourth quarter, especially around some of our partial business and so forth. So I think that's more of a normal thing. If you think
componenttext: Sequentially, fourth quarter to first quarter is a very different story, obviously, with the peak that we're seeing in the fourth quarter, especially around some of our partial business and so forth. So I think that's more of a normal thing. If you think about our intermodal business, there's 2 components to it. We've talked about the international side, where we have had some competitive losses, and you can continue to see that throughout '16. However, on the domestic side, we are having good continued success with our H2R initiative, and we're also seeing some additional kind of outsized growth here over the last, probably, 6 months, and will probably continue in the first half of next year, where we have one domestic customer that is continuing to shift, I guess, additional traffic to us, which is really a decision that they have made. It's nothing that we have done to incentivize that. They seem to have wanted to diversify their portfolio. And as a result, we think the domestic business will continue to be strong, at least for the first half of the year and probably beyond that. We still think there's opportunity to grow even if that shift subsides.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And as a follow-up, when do you lap the final piece of the international competitor losses? Is that -- should I think about that as Q4 of '16 or earlier?
componenttext: Got it. And as a follow-up, when do you lap the final piece of the international competitor losses? Is that -- should I think about that as Q4 of '16 or earlier?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that is correct, Q4 of '16.
componenttext: Yes, that is correct, Q4 of '16.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: And is that the end or beginning?
componenttext: And is that the end or beginning?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, no. So we will have one account that we're just really kicking in and having lost here in the first quarter. You will see the whole [ph] through all of '16.
componenttext: No, no. So we will have one account that we're just really kicking in and having lost here in the first quarter. You will see the whole [ph] through all of '16.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question will be coming from Alex Vecchio from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: The next question will be coming from Alex Vecchio from Morgan Stanley.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question is with respect to the guidance for earnings to be down next year. You guys had called out about $180 million of tailwinds in 2015 from property gains and liquidated damages, which is roughly $0.11 to $0.12 a share. So my question is if we wer
componenttext: My question is with respect to the guidance for earnings to be down next year. You guys had called out about $180 million of tailwinds in 2015 from property gains and liquidated damages, which is roughly $0.11 to $0.12 a share. So my question is if we were to kind of normalize for those numbers, would you still expect your core, if you will, EPS to be down in 2016? Or would it be roughly flat if we were to normalize for those figures?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think we gave you a couple of the data points to look at. Clearly, we gave you new coal guidance today that is down from what we had telegraphed on the third quarter call, so that's clearly something to think through. And then on the broader merchand
componenttext: So I think we gave you a couple of the data points to look at. Clearly, we gave you new coal guidance today that is down from what we had telegraphed on the third quarter call, so that's clearly something to think through. And then on the broader merchandise side, with the industrial sector a little sluggish here, so that's some cost. But then again, on the other side, continued strong pricing for an improved service product and efficiencies and rightsizing. So there's going to be some pluses and minuses as we go forward. But in terms of your original way of thinking about it, I mean, you do have to normalize it and then really look at the pluses and minuses from there.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the other thing I would add to that, Alex, is, obviously, over the last couple of years, we've been able to grow our other markets to offset the decline in coal. So we're going to have a continuing decline in coal here, and an uncertain industrial eco
componenttext: And the other thing I would add to that, Alex, is, obviously, over the last couple of years, we've been able to grow our other markets to offset the decline in coal. So we're going to have a continuing decline in coal here, and an uncertain industrial economy. So again, that's the piece that's the least clear, but I think it really depends on what happens with the rest of that market. We know we'll get the productivity. We know we'll continue to network size properly. We know we'll do the pricing. So really the wildcard in that question would be what does the rest of the economy do.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that makes sense. That's helpful. And then just a quick follow-up on the first quarter guidance. Can you maybe help us quantify a little bit how much of year-over-year tailwinds you'd expect the lower incentive comp to be on the labor expense line i
componenttext: Okay, that makes sense. That's helpful. And then just a quick follow-up on the first quarter guidance. Can you maybe help us quantify a little bit how much of year-over-year tailwinds you'd expect the lower incentive comp to be on the labor expense line in the first quarter, and maybe through 2016?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So obviously, on the incentive comp, the plan resets at the beginning of every year. So we had favorability in the back half of 2015 as the year played out differently than we had originally projected, and we disclosed that to you on a quarterly basi
componenttext: Yes. So obviously, on the incentive comp, the plan resets at the beginning of every year. So we had favorability in the back half of 2015 as the year played out differently than we had originally projected, and we disclosed that to you on a quarterly basis, so be on the lookout for that one. In terms of the Q1 EPS, obviously, based on the cycling of the $100 million in liquidated damages in a different demand environment of the first quarter of '15 versus the first quarter of '16, especially in coal, that's going to impact us in the demand environment that we talked about. But again, you're going to have to look at the improved service and the rightsizing and the efficiencies and the pricing performance, and that will ultimately help us give some guidance in terms of how far quarter 1 of '16 will be down versus reported '15.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will be coming from Jason Seidl from Cowen.
componenttext: Our next question will be coming from Jason Seidl from Cowen.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fred, I wanted to go back to something. I think, you commented about your truck competitive pricing. You mentioned that although truck spot pricing was down, contract was holding up. If contract starts to roll over to sort of meet where spot is, how much
componenttext: Fred, I wanted to go back to something. I think, you commented about your truck competitive pricing. You mentioned that although truck spot pricing was down, contract was holding up. If contract starts to roll over to sort of meet where spot is, how much pressure is that going to put on intermodal pricing? How should we look at that?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I do think that we are, I'll say, holding up okay. It's clearly gotten softer throughout the year, even on the contract side. And intermodal side is where we do see most of that direct pressure. Now you know that still we have a probably 10% to 15% g
componenttext: Yes. I do think that we are, I'll say, holding up okay. It's clearly gotten softer throughout the year, even on the contract side. And intermodal side is where we do see most of that direct pressure. Now you know that still we have a probably 10% to 15% gap between what the truck prices are and what -- where our prices are. And one of the key things in intermodal space is the strong service product. And as we think about our service product here, this year entering into '16, it is clear that it's very different than it was a year ago, and that is also going to be very helpful as we approach contract season and we put new contracts in place.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, but in terms of -- if you just say your mix and service improvements and you see the truck pricing take a step down, is it going to be tougher to maintain your pricing even with a superior service product?
componenttext: Okay, but in terms of -- if you just say your mix and service improvements and you see the truck pricing take a step down, is it going to be tougher to maintain your pricing even with a superior service product?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's true. I think we tried to stay away from forecast pricing, but directionally, you're right. Obviously, the longer this softness is there, the harder it's going to be to maintain. The key challenge for our team is to make sure that our custome
componenttext: I think it's true. I think we tried to stay away from forecast pricing, but directionally, you're right. Obviously, the longer this softness is there, the harder it's going to be to maintain. The key challenge for our team is to make sure that our customers are aware that while there's a softness here right now in '16, I think all of us still know that the macro drivers that we talked about for a long time are still prevalent. As we think about some of the productivity challenges that the trucking industry would face as we get to '17 with electronic logs, as unemployment continues to come down, it's going to be harder to retain the drivers without outsized increases in driver pay. So we are facing a softness. I think also, though, our customers are acknowledging that, that is probably temporary as some of these macro factors will come back into play.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fantastic, and my follow-up. Michael, given the recent comments by the STB on mergers and also the proposed merger or the talked-about merger, I guess, between CP and NS, what's the likelihood that you see that the current board would approve a combinatio
componenttext: Fantastic, and my follow-up. Michael, given the recent comments by the STB on mergers and also the proposed merger or the talked-about merger, I guess, between CP and NS, what's the likelihood that you see that the current board would approve a combination?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that's a very timely and a difficult question to answer, Jason. As you know, there hasn't been any mergers under the current regulatory environment. Now it is a really complicated question. It's probably better addressed by the STB. But as you saw b
componenttext: Well, that's a very timely and a difficult question to answer, Jason. As you know, there hasn't been any mergers under the current regulatory environment. Now it is a really complicated question. It's probably better addressed by the STB. But as you saw by their letter last week, they're going to be very focused on, one, the public interest of the potential merger, potential downstream effects. And I think the thing that's probably the most uncertain, but probably going to be there for sure, the question to the extent is what regulatory cost will be put on this merger?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will be coming from Matt Troy from Nomura Securities.
componenttext: Our next question will be coming from Matt Troy from Nomura Securities.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to ask with respect to pricing, obviously, rail's peripherally or tangentially tied to the commodity super cycle, which is winding down. You've got some more bearish people out there talking about rail pricing being vulnerable, anecdotes of ca
componenttext: Just wanted to ask with respect to pricing, obviously, rail's peripherally or tangentially tied to the commodity super cycle, which is winding down. You've got some more bearish people out there talking about rail pricing being vulnerable, anecdotes of carriers cutting price to incent volume. I just wanted to hear from you or confirm with you that you still remain committed to inflation-plus type pricing consistent with similar years and that there hasn't been a change in thought or philosophy that perhaps price might be a lever you might use to incent volume in 2016.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think our philosophy is still there, hasn't changed in terms of making sure that we do value pricing that reflects the value price of our customers, and being able to continue to reinvest in our business. At the end of the day, it goes back to what
componenttext: No. I think our philosophy is still there, hasn't changed in terms of making sure that we do value pricing that reflects the value price of our customers, and being able to continue to reinvest in our business. At the end of the day, it goes back to what is the second best option for our customers from a service and enterprise perspective. As we think through each one of them, we still think that we have an opportunity to continue to make sure we get the pricing that we need to continue to reinvest in our business, which benefits both our shareholders but also our customers as we continue to strengthen our infrastructure. There is one market where we have consistently said that it makes sense in this kind of commodity downturn to be flexible because we've seen we've got additional demand by doing so, and that's our export coal market. And we've taken some additional action here in the fourth quarter to reflect a very, very difficult and challenging environment for them. But in the rest of the markets, we work with our customers in partnership and try to figure out what the best service product is and at the same time also make sure we get the appropriate price. So I would say that nothing has changed in terms of the philosophy that you've seen here from CSX for more than a decade.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great answer. And then I guess my quick follow-up would be the intermodal growth, obviously, you spoke at length about the loss in international, but the domestic, up 14%, was a fantastic number. You kind of have a tale of 2 railroads when you look
componenttext: Okay, great answer. And then I guess my quick follow-up would be the intermodal growth, obviously, you spoke at length about the loss in international, but the domestic, up 14%, was a fantastic number. You kind of have a tale of 2 railroads when you look at average volumes in the fourth quarter. You guys were up mid-single digits. Your competitors were down. So obviously, domestic, you alluded to a contract moving over on its own, not you incenting it. Just wondering if you could talk about that 14%, really high level directionally. How much of that growth would be that singular contract which you've seen shift? And how much of it would be what I'd refer to as more organic highway-to-rail conversion?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: It is a significant portion of that growth. I think that prior to last year, we've been growing our domestic intermodal business about 7%, and we've guided long term to about 5% to 10%. And with this softer market, we're probably at the low end of that ra
componenttext: It is a significant portion of that growth. I think that prior to last year, we've been growing our domestic intermodal business about 7%, and we've guided long term to about 5% to 10%. And with this softer market, we're probably at the low end of that range if you exclude this kind of shift. But nothing has changed in terms of our opportunity to convert what we've said is over 9 million units in our network territory that we think, over time, can be converted to a rail-based solution in partnership with our truckers. And so we think that it's softer right now, but as I said to a previous -- answer to a previous question, the macro environment still favors a rail-based solution longer term.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will be coming from Cherilyn Radbourne from TD Securities.
componenttext: Our next question will be coming from Cherilyn Radbourne from TD Securities.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question is on your variable train scheduling initiative, and just how much of an impact that had on the increase in train lengths that you saw? And what inning you think we're in, in terms of realizing the full benefits?
componenttext: My first question is on your variable train scheduling initiative, and just how much of an impact that had on the increase in train lengths that you saw? And what inning you think we're in, in terms of realizing the full benefits?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, Cherilyn. I think as far as the variable trains, which -- that applies to our merchandise network, I think we've seen the biggest increase in train size in the merchandise side. So in the fourth quarter, we saw increases in train size of 23%
componenttext: Good morning, Cherilyn. I think as far as the variable trains, which -- that applies to our merchandise network, I think we've seen the biggest increase in train size in the merchandise side. So in the fourth quarter, we saw increases in train size of 23%. So I think what the variable schedule does for us going forward is as we see softer demand, we are able to rightsize that network more effectively. In terms of what the -- what the components are of variable train that are in place, we've pretty much got them in place, but it does allow us to continue to shift and expand and contract on a more effective way than we've been able to do in the past on our merchandise network.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: And you're doing a lot more in the bulk.
componenttext: And you're doing a lot more in the bulk.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, we're also continuing train size -- train length initiatives on the bulk side as well. We've seen increases in train lengths across coal, grain and others in the 5% to 10% range also over the quarter. So it's not just a merchandise -- train len
componenttext: Yes, well, we're also continuing train size -- train length initiatives on the bulk side as well. We've seen increases in train lengths across coal, grain and others in the 5% to 10% range also over the quarter. So it's not just a merchandise -- train length is not just a merchandise initiative. It also follows the rest, but merchandise has seen the biggest benefits.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then to the extent that you expect earnings to decline in 2016 and see some volume uncertainty, can you just comment on whether that will have any impact on the pace at which you expect to execute on your share buyback program?
componenttext: Great. And then to the extent that you expect earnings to decline in 2016 and see some volume uncertainty, can you just comment on whether that will have any impact on the pace at which you expect to execute on your share buyback program?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Cherilyn, it's Frank. You saw us repurchase 9 million shares in the quarter for just under $260 million, which was essentially the same rate that you saw in the third quarter, and it's consistent with the $2 billion program that we announced back in April
componenttext: Cherilyn, it's Frank. You saw us repurchase 9 million shares in the quarter for just under $260 million, which was essentially the same rate that you saw in the third quarter, and it's consistent with the $2 billion program that we announced back in April. And we currently expect to complete that program ratably over the next 5 quarters using balance sheet cash, free cash flow and debt. So I think you're going to continue to see us, based on what we see now, to continue on that ratable program.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will be coming from Ben Hartford from Baird.
componenttext: Our next question will be coming from Ben Hartford from Baird.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question on the export coal side. In your mind, what is the risk of further downside? You obviously talked about some downside risk to the 20 million tons number this year. But what provides any sort of comfort that you have line of sight to
componenttext: Just a quick question on the export coal side. In your mind, what is the risk of further downside? You obviously talked about some downside risk to the 20 million tons number this year. But what provides any sort of comfort that you have line of sight to a floor and that we shouldn't be thinking about the early 2000s levels of a number less than half this guided 2016 number, or even something above and beyond the 2002, 2003 levels? Is there any way to frame -- well obviously, the market's uncertain, but is there any way to frame up the likelihood of a 50% or even deeper cut to the export coal number over the course of the next few years?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think that over the last couple of years, as we've provided you guidance at the beginning of the year, we've been actually very, very close to those numbers. And while these are uncharted territory in terms of kind of the underlying commodity pric
componenttext: Sure. I think that over the last couple of years, as we've provided you guidance at the beginning of the year, we've been actually very, very close to those numbers. And while these are uncharted territory in terms of kind of the underlying commodity prices, both on the thermal side and the met side, we do work very closely with our customers, both on the producer side and also with some of the agents that sell for us and really try to go over and understand the markets themselves. And as we think about '16 right now, out of the 20 million, we probably have about 6 million that we very good visibility to, probably a little bit lower than you normally would have at this time of the year. But we still think that there's an opportunity to get to that about that 20 million tons for the year, and one of the drivers here is also that you do have such a large excess surplus of domestic coal, where the producers are very eager to push that out into the world market, and that is helpful as well as we move through 2016.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. I guess we'll just watch how that develops through the year. Frank, share buyback, what is the thought process there this year? And then I want to confirm something on the CapEx side, the $307 million from the 113 locos that were pur
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. I guess we'll just watch how that develops through the year. Frank, share buyback, what is the thought process there this year? And then I want to confirm something on the CapEx side, the $307 million from the 113 locos that were purchased late last year. Is that in the 2016 CapEx budget of $2.4 billion?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the answer to your last question is yes. And on the buybacks, it's the same ratable methodology that you've heard us talk about previously. And so the $2 billion program was intended to be over a 2-year period, and as we currently see things, we'll con
componenttext: So the answer to your last question is yes. And on the buybacks, it's the same ratable methodology that you've heard us talk about previously. And so the $2 billion program was intended to be over a 2-year period, and as we currently see things, we'll continue to do it at about $260 million a quarter.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question will be coming from David Vernon from Bernstein.
componenttext: The next question will be coming from David Vernon from Bernstein.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fredrik, maybe just to put some more numbers on the issue around utility coal pricing. If you look back over the last couple of years when you've seen the utility business kind of get cut by half or so, can you talk about the trend you guys have seen in y
componenttext: Fredrik, maybe just to put some more numbers on the issue around utility coal pricing. If you look back over the last couple of years when you've seen the utility business kind of get cut by half or so, can you talk about the trend you guys have seen in your sort of distance-neutral rate per ton? Has that been moving up? Or have you seen some weaker years went because of the lower gas price? Have you seen it -- just trying to kind of put some numbers around the utility coal pricing?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So clearly, in the kind of mid part of last decade, there was a significant opportunity to touch legacy pricing and that probably lasted from 2005 to 2011 or so. And then since then, it's been much more normalized pricing. And as natural gas prices n
componenttext: Yes. So clearly, in the kind of mid part of last decade, there was a significant opportunity to touch legacy pricing and that probably lasted from 2005 to 2011 or so. And then since then, it's been much more normalized pricing. And as natural gas prices now have come down as much as they have, there really isn't much that we can do to incentivize incremental burn. We look at each and every contract when they come up to see if there's -- there are opportunities to optimize the bottom line by being more flexible in pricing. And if there is, we'll do that. But generally, at these natural gas prices, there isn't any -- really anything we can do to improve the burn rate, with maybe 1 or 2 exceptions.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then maybe, Frank, just as a follow-up on the productivity, can you talk a little bit about how dependent the level of productivity you're getting right now is on the CapEx budget? It sounds like some of the new locomotives that you're getting a
componenttext: Okay. And then maybe, Frank, just as a follow-up on the productivity, can you talk a little bit about how dependent the level of productivity you're getting right now is on the CapEx budget? It sounds like some of the new locomotives that you're getting are necessary to run the longer trains. And I'm just wondering about how much more upgrading of the fleet may be required over the next few years, and when that CapEx number can get down to 16%, 17%.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right, David. So on the locomotive piece, obviously, we'll complete the deliveries in 2016. As Cindy has or will mention, we've certainly looked at rightsizing the fleet and taking out the bad actors and the high-fuel-burn locomotives. So it certainly hel
componenttext: Right, David. So on the locomotive piece, obviously, we'll complete the deliveries in 2016. As Cindy has or will mention, we've certainly looked at rightsizing the fleet and taking out the bad actors and the high-fuel-burn locomotives. So it certainly helps, but you're talking about 300 engines on a 4,000-engine base. On your tie between productivity and CapEx, there's always some in the CapEx budget that relates to productivity, and it's really a -- I'd say a dog's breakfast, right? You've got structural changes in the coal network. You've got G&A restructuring and downsizing. You've got internal efficiencies. You got train length, which gives you lower crew starts, as we've mentioned earlier in the call. You've got technology initiatives, which are funded through the CapEx process that relate into some of the productivity initiatives. So I think you're looking at a lot of things that we did in 2015 that'll carry over into 2016. And then there's a little bit of a tie between CapEx and productivity, but it's small in the grand scheme of things, David. In terms of long term and getting back down to 16% to 17%, if you were to just normalize this year's capital budget for the $300 million in locomotive payments, you'd be at that range now. So it's certainly something that on a long-term basis we're going to continue to look at. Fuel surcharges, that's come down, has obviously been a bit of a headwind for us in the past as we look at that 16% to 17%.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I guess just as a short follow-up to that, and in a number of -- the 300 locos that you've taken against the 4,000 fleet, if you had sort of a capital-unconstrained world and you wanted to go and push train lengths in other parts of the business, woul
componenttext: And I guess just as a short follow-up to that, and in a number of -- the 300 locos that you've taken against the 4,000 fleet, if you had sort of a capital-unconstrained world and you wanted to go and push train lengths in other parts of the business, would there be opportunities to go ahead and continue to upgrade that fleet and operationally find opportunities to run longer trains in other parts of the network? Or are you nearing the end of the ability to kind of get that extra productivity from train length?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, this is Cindy. The train length constraints really are not locomotive based. They're siding, capacity-based in the southern part of our network. And in terms of capital, we're looking at those types of investments going forward to allow us to unloc
componenttext: David, this is Cindy. The train length constraints really are not locomotive based. They're siding, capacity-based in the southern part of our network. And in terms of capital, we're looking at those types of investments going forward to allow us to unlock the value of longer trains. So it's really not locomotive based.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will be coming from John Larkin from Stifel.
componenttext: Our next question will be coming from John Larkin from Stifel.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to dig a little bit more into the stated objective of producing another $200 million in productivity savings in 2016. Could we talk a little bit about how that might be spread over the year and how much of that is tied to the rationalization of the
componenttext: Wanted to dig a little bit more into the stated objective of producing another $200 million in productivity savings in 2016. Could we talk a little bit about how that might be spread over the year and how much of that is tied to the rationalization of the coal network, and whether the rationalization of the coal network also would envision potential abandonments and/or sales to short lines on some lighter-density lines in the coal network?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, this is Cindy. So from a productivity perspective, the $200 million is -- and again, as I'd said, initiative based. $100 million is pretty much those initiatives are in place. Two of those, or 1 area that's included, is the actions that we took in t
componenttext: John, this is Cindy. So from a productivity perspective, the $200 million is -- and again, as I'd said, initiative based. $100 million is pretty much those initiatives are in place. Two of those, or 1 area that's included, is the actions that we took in the fourth quarter on the reduction in volume across the Erwin gateway and the closure of the Corbin locomotive facilities. So to the extent those are obviously in the coal fields, that is an impact to productivity in 2016 around both facilities, reduction in facilities and headcount reductions. So that's basically the way I see 2016 looking with productivity. As far as continued rationalization in the coalfields, as I said, we're going to look at that, not just in the coalfields but broadly, whether it's facility related and/or line segment. The line segments take a little bit longer to work through. They involve customers, they involve their constituencies. So as we make those determinations and make those decisions, we'll be very public with that information. But that's more longer term.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: So that $200 million will be folded in pretty much evenly across all 4 quarters. Is that a way to think about it?
componenttext: So that $200 million will be folded in pretty much evenly across all 4 quarters. Is that a way to think about it?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say it's ratable, John, yes. I would say it's probably the easiest way to think about it.
componenttext: Yes, I would say it's ratable, John, yes. I would say it's probably the easiest way to think about it.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question will be coming from Bascome Majors from Susquehanna.
componenttext: Next question will be coming from Bascome Majors from Susquehanna.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to take a directional look at the margin profile of the coal business. It looks like on your guidance, tonnage is going to be -- if you're at your guidance for the year, tonnage will be down 45% or so for the entire business since 2011. Can you jus
componenttext: I want to take a directional look at the margin profile of the coal business. It looks like on your guidance, tonnage is going to be -- if you're at your guidance for the year, tonnage will be down 45% or so for the entire business since 2011. Can you just talk a little bit about the balance within the segment of the margin profile between the export business today, after the price cuts you've taken over several years, and the domestic business, where you transitioned to the fixed variable contract structure? And also more broadly, where is coal comp-ing versus the rest of the book today? Is it still your premium business, up there with chemicals? Or has the profile fallen down the ladder a bit as the revenues have fallen?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So this is Fredrik. Back in 2012 or so, we used to say that our export and utility business was about the same level of contribution and -- on a margin basis. But since then, as we have adjusted export rates significantly down, our utility book of b
componenttext: Sure. So this is Fredrik. Back in 2012 or so, we used to say that our export and utility business was about the same level of contribution and -- on a margin basis. But since then, as we have adjusted export rates significantly down, our utility book of business has a higher margin than the export business. If you look at the overall portfolio of coal versus the rest of the business, I would say that it's still clearly more profitable because of the fact that it's such an efficient way for us to move the cargo. Heavy tonnage, just the unit train back and forth, it's very, very efficient for us to operate that way. And so it's still at the high end of our business.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: As my follow-up here, and maybe for Michael or Clarence, if he's in the room. I understand you guys are railroaders, you're not economists here. But just looking at the volume declines you're seeing today, both the depth of them and the breadth, I mean, h
componenttext: As my follow-up here, and maybe for Michael or Clarence, if he's in the room. I understand you guys are railroaders, you're not economists here. But just looking at the volume declines you're seeing today, both the depth of them and the breadth, I mean, have you ever seen an environment like this in your business or careers outside of a recession?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Michael. I'll answer that, although Clarence is here. So if you take out the recession, no, we've not seen these kind of pressures in so many different markets because you have multiple aspects working against you. The low gas prices, the low comm
componenttext: This is Michael. I'll answer that, although Clarence is here. So if you take out the recession, no, we've not seen these kind of pressures in so many different markets because you have multiple aspects working against you. The low gas prices, the low commodity prices, the strength of the dollar, all 3 of those together are really pushing. And in some ways, I think you can almost think of it as a freight recession. Except for, say, markets like automotive and housing related, you're seeing pressure on most of the markets. So clearly, outside of a recession, this is one where we're seeing lots of pressure in lots of different markets.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will be coming from Jeff Kauffman from Buckingham Research.
componenttext: Our next question will be coming from Jeff Kauffman from Buckingham Research.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, congratulations. I mean, just a very difficult quarter. I thought you guys did a great job on the cost side. I wanted to zero in on the change in coal guidance for next year. If I look at kind of what's changed, I think you were talkin
componenttext: Well, first of all, congratulations. I mean, just a very difficult quarter. I thought you guys did a great job on the cost side. I wanted to zero in on the change in coal guidance for next year. If I look at kind of what's changed, I think you were talking around kind of a 21 million ton domestic run rate going down to 19 million, so that's about an 8 million ton change. But it really looks like almost half of that drop was on the coking coal and domestic met side. So 2 questions. Number one, when I look at domestic, how much of that change is your view on utility versus your view on kind of other domestic coal? And when I look at the exports, you did about 31 million this year. The guidance is for 20 million. Can I look at end markets, and can we think about it that way in terms of where has the incremental demand ebbed for your export coal geographically?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So yes, you're right. If you go back to the third quarter guidance that we did at the call, we essentially said 21 million tons per quarter of domestic, which was 15 million of domestic -- of utility and 6 million of steel and industrial. And what w
componenttext: Sure. So yes, you're right. If you go back to the third quarter guidance that we did at the call, we essentially said 21 million tons per quarter of domestic, which was 15 million of domestic -- of utility and 6 million of steel and industrial. And what we said then about our export was about 6 million tons a quarter for 24 million in total. So we've essentially seen a deterioration in all of those 3 markets by about 1 million tons a quarter, and it's really a reflection of the fact that natural gas prices and the very mild fourth quarter on the utility side has dampened our expectations. On the steel and industrial side, it's the reflection of the fact that when we look at the steel industry right now, you're having utilization of about 60% versus 75% a year ago, and we saw it deteriorate throughout the fourth quarter. And on the export market, it's also just a reflection of the fact that underlying commodity indexes are telling us that the market has gotten softer as global oversupply continues. So in terms of where the export market is going, we did about 60-40 split here between meth and thermal. They'll probably a little bit higher next year, would be my guess at this point in terms of probably 1/3-2/3, 2/3 in favor of meth. And traditionally, over half of our business goes to Europe, but I would say that split is probably going to continue in terms of the end market as well. And so I think it's just proportional between the markets, and I think you're going to see relatively proportional cut in terms of the end markets as well.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is coming from Scott Group from Wolfe Research.
componenttext: The next question is coming from Scott Group from Wolfe Research.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Fredrik, I just wanted to ask about the coal yields. So I thought that the fixed variable was supposed to kind of help in environments like this when volumes are down so much and kind of help the yields out. Why aren't we seeing that?
componenttext: So Fredrik, I just wanted to ask about the coal yields. So I thought that the fixed variable was supposed to kind of help in environments like this when volumes are down so much and kind of help the yields out. Why aren't we seeing that?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. In the third quarter, they were very helpful, actually. They were still helpful here in the fourth quarter, but not as much because some of this also depends on who you're actually shipping to. And the big driver, though, in the coal yields was reall
componenttext: Yes. In the third quarter, they were very helpful, actually. They were still helpful here in the fourth quarter, but not as much because some of this also depends on who you're actually shipping to. And the big driver, though, in the coal yields was really the fact that we have made these accommodations on the export side and further adjusted our rates downward to reflect the reality of the underlying market, and at the same time trying to optimize our bottom line.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then Michael, I just want to ask. So a lot's changed at CSX. Certainly, a lot has changed in the market from a year ago, 1.5 years ago. Does your view or appetite on M&A change at all or has it changed at all in that year, 1.5 years?
componenttext: Okay. And then Michael, I just want to ask. So a lot's changed at CSX. Certainly, a lot has changed in the market from a year ago, 1.5 years ago. Does your view or appetite on M&A change at all or has it changed at all in that year, 1.5 years?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not really, Scott. If you think about it, I think our position is the same as it was a year, 1.5 years ago. We think there's tremendous opportunity for shareholder value creation with our existing portfolio. And if you think about any mergers, there's goi
componenttext: Not really, Scott. If you think about it, I think our position is the same as it was a year, 1.5 years ago. We think there's tremendous opportunity for shareholder value creation with our existing portfolio. And if you think about any mergers, there's going to be substantial regulatory cost. Some of the synergies will be very limited because they're end-to-end mergers. So if you're going to offset those regulatory costs, you got to have compelling interfaces and synergies, and I really have a hard time envisioning where that would be in any rail merger.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the challenges of the market don't change your view on that.
componenttext: So the challenges of the market don't change your view on that.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, sir. I think we've done well in prior down periods. We think we will in this one as well. And within [ph] the long-term future, with our existing customer base, 2/3 of the population we serve, pressures on the trucking, the service improvements we'll
componenttext: No, sir. I think we've done well in prior down periods. We think we will in this one as well. And within [ph] the long-term future, with our existing customer base, 2/3 of the population we serve, pressures on the trucking, the service improvements we'll continue to make in the pricing, allow us to create lots of value for the shareholders over the intermediate long term.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is coming from Justin Long from Stephens.
componenttext: The next question is coming from Justin Long from Stephens.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you talked about cycling the benefits from liquidated damages and gains on sale this year. And just taking those items out, to someone's point earlier, you get to a mid-single-digit EPS decline in 2016. Along with anticipated volume declines, mix headw
componenttext: So you talked about cycling the benefits from liquidated damages and gains on sale this year. And just taking those items out, to someone's point earlier, you get to a mid-single-digit EPS decline in 2016. Along with anticipated volume declines, mix headwinds, your commentary that it will be difficult to improve the OR, is it fair to say the EPS should be down at least double digits or low double digits this year?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, all we're prepared to talk to you about today is the directional piece. What we tried to do is to give you some clarity around the moving parts that we have, obviously, certainty on the cycling piece, and we have we think good insights into the coal
componenttext: Yes, all we're prepared to talk to you about today is the directional piece. What we tried to do is to give you some clarity around the moving parts that we have, obviously, certainty on the cycling piece, and we have we think good insights into the coal sector. It's really what happens in the industrial space, especially as we get out into the second half of the year. And again, it's really, really early in the year to -- in an uncertain environment, to project the full year EPS with specificity. At the same time, you look at the things that we're doing, the pricing performance, the productivity, the rightsizing, the service improvements, I mean, all of those things are the things that are most within our control. And those are the things that you're going to see us be relentless about.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair enough. And as a quick follow-up, I wanted to ask about PTC. You mentioned the $300 million of anticipated spending this year and $2.2 billion in total. But of that total amount, what's remaining -- I guess, what's remaining after 2016? And aft
componenttext: Okay, fair enough. And as a quick follow-up, I wanted to ask about PTC. You mentioned the $300 million of anticipated spending this year and $2.2 billion in total. But of that total amount, what's remaining -- I guess, what's remaining after 2016? And after you've fully installed the technology, do you anticipate any incremental maintenance costs associated with PTC that would be ongoing?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so let me give you the facts and the figures on PTC. So $1.5 billion is what we've spent through the end of '15. We've given you the $300 million guidance for '16, so that would take you up to the $1.8 billion through the end of this year. Our projec
componenttext: Yes, so let me give you the facts and the figures on PTC. So $1.5 billion is what we've spent through the end of '15. We've given you the $300 million guidance for '16, so that would take you up to the $1.8 billion through the end of this year. Our project takes us to a hardware completion date of 2018 and fully operational by 2020. I think you'll see the majority of the difference between the $1.8 billion and the $2.2 billion being spent between now -- excuse me, end of '16 and the end of '18. In terms of the tail on OpEx and some refresh CapEx, we're still working through that. Obviously, there's a piece that's embedded within depreciation as well as in departmental operating expenses, and that's still being worked on right now as we understand the support agreements that will go along with the hardware and the software as well as the useful life on those pieces of equipment.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016

componenttext: Our next question will be coming from Cleo Zagrean from Macquarie.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: So to follow up on the recent conversation, let's imagine ourselves this time next year, after the lower earnings base set by '16. And I'm not asking for guidance, but conceptually, how do you see the new growth trend? Can we see double-digit sustainable
componenttext: So to follow up on the recent conversation, let's imagine ourselves this time next year, after the lower earnings base set by '16. And I'm not asking for guidance, but conceptually, how do you see the new growth trend? Can we see double-digit sustainable EPS growth? Or should we think of maturing into a pattern of lower growth, maybe more distribution for shareholders? Because we've been talking about the structural changes not in the so-called recession, such as low profitability from coal, consumer spending shifting more towards services, probably [ph] sustainable, strong dollar, sluggish industrial economy. So what is the new normal? And how can you grow in that?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Cleo. From just an EPS directional thinking beyond 2016, we see 2016 as, again, a unique year. And clearly, we should be able to provide strong EPS growth off of a 2016 base. And I'll allow Fredrik to comment on some of the commercial items of you
componenttext: Thanks, Cleo. From just an EPS directional thinking beyond 2016, we see 2016 as, again, a unique year. And clearly, we should be able to provide strong EPS growth off of a 2016 base. And I'll allow Fredrik to comment on some of the commercial items of your question in terms of where some of the various lines of business might be going.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, so as we go through this year and cycle some of these headwinds that we're going to be facing clearly for the first half of this year, and we look at where the macroeconomic indicators are and projection for the U.S. dollar, I think we'll sta
componenttext: Yes. I mean, so as we go through this year and cycle some of these headwinds that we're going to be facing clearly for the first half of this year, and we look at where the macroeconomic indicators are and projection for the U.S. dollar, I think we'll start seeing things stabilize and normalize and we're going to start seeing year-over-year growth as we move through, hopefully, late in 2016 and clearly moving into '17. Based on what we're seeing right now, as Frank I think has said many times throughout the call today, and Michael as well, the key thing for us, right, is to focus on the things that we control the most, and then the macro headwinds are going to be whatever they are. And the key thing for us is to adjust our infrastructure to reflect the reality of what they provide us.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as a follow-up, can you talk to us about the rate at which you see investing in growth opportunities? And maybe what it would take for you to consider a higher, sustainable dividend yield to appeal more broadly to dividend-focused investors?
componenttext: And as a follow-up, can you talk to us about the rate at which you see investing in growth opportunities? And maybe what it would take for you to consider a higher, sustainable dividend yield to appeal more broadly to dividend-focused investors?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, on the capital side, clearly, there's a portion of our capital budget every year that is geared toward growth investments. The majority of that, over recent years, has been focused on our growth engine and that's on the intermodal, especially on the
componenttext: Well, on the capital side, clearly, there's a portion of our capital budget every year that is geared toward growth investments. The majority of that, over recent years, has been focused on our growth engine and that's on the intermodal, especially on the domestic intermodal side. So you'll continue to see us focus in that area. In terms of dividends, I'd say currently where we are, we have a very healthy yield. We have guidance out there in terms of what we're willing to pay out on a trailing 12-months basis, and that's in the 30% to 40% of trailing 12-months earnings. And so we look at that every year, generally speaking, after the first quarter. And we'll continue to do that and look at where we are against the broader environment.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the last question will be coming from Keith Schoonmaker from Morningstar.
componenttext: And the last question will be coming from Keith Schoonmaker from Morningstar.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your expectations for automotive were scarce bright spots, as were actual auto shipments last year. Could you please add some color to this growth expectation, maybe particular locations where you're seeing some strengths as well as, perhaps, comment on g
componenttext: Your expectations for automotive were scarce bright spots, as were actual auto shipments last year. Could you please add some color to this growth expectation, maybe particular locations where you're seeing some strengths as well as, perhaps, comment on general shifts of production to Mexico and how that affects your network?

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So if we look at the North American light vehicle production, I think we're ending up about 17.5 million here in '15 and the projection is for 18.2 million next year. So that provides us good growth opportunities. U.S. sales, also based on the proje
componenttext: Sure. So if we look at the North American light vehicle production, I think we're ending up about 17.5 million here in '15 and the projection is for 18.2 million next year. So that provides us good growth opportunities. U.S. sales, also based on the projections that we're seeing, indicates good growth. The Mexico shift is clear, so the North American light vehicle production numbers are probably skewed a little bit more towards Mexico, which we don't capture as much of but we still capture some of that. And sometimes, that is actually a length-of-haul advantage for us, so that is helpful. So overall, if you go back in history over the last 30, 40 years, I'm sure that you'll find that our correlation to the North American light vehicle production is probably in the very, very high 95%, 98%. So we follow what producers tell us and then we adjust our fleet and service accordingly. And right now, it looks like we're going to have another year of growth. But not even close where it's been since '09, but still a nice growth. And especially in this sort of environment, we need these sort of growth opportunities.

headline: CSX Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 13, 2016
