headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the CSX Corporation First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] For opening remarks and introduction, I would like to turn the call over to Mr.
componenttext: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the CSX Corporation First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] For opening remarks and introduction, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. David Baggs, Vice President, Treasurer and Investor Relations Officer for CSX Corporation.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Nicole, and good morning, everyone. And welcome, again, to CSX Corporation's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Presentation. The presentation material that we'll be reviewing this morning, along with our expanded quarterly financial report and our
componenttext:
Thank you, Nicole, and good morning, everyone. And welcome, again, to CSX Corporation's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Presentation. 
The presentation material that we'll be reviewing this morning, along with our expanded quarterly financial report and our safety and service measurements, are available on our website at csx.com under the Investors section. 
In addition, following the presentation this morning, a webcast replay will be available on that same website. 
This morning, our presentation will be led by Michael Ward, the company's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Frank Lonegro, our Chief Financial Officer. 
In addition, Cindy Sanborn, our Chief Operating Officer; and Fredrik Eliasson, our Chief Sales and Marketing Officer; along with Clarence Gooden, our President, will be available during the question-and-answer session. 
Now before I turn the presentation over to Michael, let me remind everyone that the presentation and other statements made by the company contain forward-looking statements. You are encouraged to review the company's disclosure on the accompanying presentation on Slide 2. This disclosure identifies forward-looking statements as well as the uncertainties and risks that could cause actual performance to differ materially from the results anticipated by these statements. 
In addition, at the end of the presentation, we will conduct a question-and-answer session with the research analysts. [Operator Instructions] 
And with that, let me turn the presentation over to CSX Corporation's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Michael Ward. Michael?

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, David. Good morning, everyone. Yesterday, CSX reported first quarter earnings per share of $0.37 compared to $0.45 per share in the same period last year. Revenue declined 14% in the quarter, a strong pricing across nearly all markets ref
componenttext:
Well, thank you, David. Good morning, everyone. Yesterday, CSX reported first quarter earnings per share of $0.37 compared to $0.45 per share in the same period last year. Revenue declined 14% in the quarter, a strong pricing across nearly all markets reflecting an improving service product, was more than offset by the impact of lower fuel recovery, market conditions that drove a 5% volume decline, including a 31% decline in coal and a $95 million year-over-year decline in liquidated damages. Turning to operations. CSX remained an industry leader in safety and service measurements continued to advance in the quarter, consistent with our service excellence initiative to meet and exceed customer expectations. 
Expenses improved 12%, driven by lower fuel prices as well as efficiency gains and lower volume related costs, reflecting CSX's ongoing drive to aggressively reduce its cost structure as we continue to reshape the company in face of this challenging market environment. 
Including the impact of these cost-saving actions and the decline in liquidated damages, operating income decreased $139 million to $704 million for the quarter. At the same time, the operating ratio increased 90 basis points year-over-year to 73.1. 
Now I'll turn the presentation over to Frank, who will take us through the results and second quarter outlook in more detail.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michael, and good morning, everyone. Let me begin by providing more detail on our first quarter results. As Michael mentioned, revenue was down 14% or $409 million versus the prior year. With coal declining 31%, total volume decreased 5% from
componenttext:
Thank you, Michael, and good morning, everyone. 
Let me begin by providing more detail on our first quarter results. As Michael mentioned, revenue was down 14% or $409 million versus the prior year. With coal declining 31%, total volume decreased 5% from last year, which impacted revenue by about $140 million. 
In addition, fuel surcharge recovery declined $139 million. 
We continue to see strong core pricing from an improving service product, which for the first quarter was up 3.1% overall and 4.0%, excluding coal.  However, these gains were more than offset by the impact of negative business mix in the quarter. 
Other revenue decreased $85 million, driven mainly by cycling higher liquidated damages from last year, which totaled $105 million versus $10 million in this year's first quarter. 
Expenses decreased 12% versus the prior year, driven mainly by $133 million in efficiency gains, $78 million in lower fuel prices and $64 million in lower volume related costs. 
Operating income was $704 million in the first quarter, down 16% versus the prior year. 
Looking below the line, interest expense was up slightly from last year, with higher debt levels partially offset by lower rates, while other income was relatively flat to the prior year. 
Then finally, income taxes were $212 million in the quarter, with an effective tax rate of about 37%. 
Overall, net earnings were $356 million, down 19% versus the prior year and EPS was $0.37 per share, down 18% versus last year. 
Now let me turn to the market outlook for the second quarter. Looking forward, we, again, expect volumes to decline in the second quarter. The challenging freight environment will continue as headwinds in coal, energy and metals volume are expected to more than offset the markets that will show growth. Automotive is expected to grow as light vehicle production continues to be a bright spot in the economy. Minerals will benefit from the continued ramp up of a new flash remediation project and continued highway construction driving aggregates movement. 
Intermodal is expected to be neutral as we continue to cycle competitive international losses. This will be offset by secular domestic growth, driven by strategic investments supporting highway-to-rail conversion. Chemicals volume is expected to decline as energy markets continue to be marked by low crude oil prices and reduced drilling activity, which will impact our shale-related products more significantly in the second quarter. 
At the same time, the core chemical markets remain healthy. 
Domestic coal will continue to be unfavorably impacted by low natural gas prices currently around $2 and high levels of coal inventory at the utilities. As a result, we expect second quarter tonnage to be around 18 million tons. 
In addition, we anticipate a similar quarterly run rate for the second half, recognizing domestic coal volume will be largely dependent on weather. 
Export coal remains pressured by the strong U.S. dollar and global oversupply. As a result, we believe second quarter tonnage will be around 4 million to 5 million tons and expect a similar run rate for the remainder of the year. 
For the full year, we now expect around 18 million to 20 million tons of export coal in 2016. 
Despite a slowly recovering domestic steel production environment, metal is expected to be unfavorable year-over-year as the market works off excess supply from a strong U.S. dollar and imported products. 
Overall, we are still facing significant coal headwinds and a freight environment that continues to experience pronounced challenges associated with historically low crude oil, natural gas and other commodity prices and a strong U.S. dollar. 
As a result, we expect second quarter volume to decline in the mid- to high-single-digit range year-over-year. 
Turning to the next slide, let me talk about our expectations for expenses in the second quarter. 
We expect second quarter expense to benefit from the low fuel price environment and our ongoing focus on driving efficiency gains and rightsizing resources as we continue to reshape the company. 
Over the course of the last 12 months, we have taken aggressive cost actions with headcount down nearly 4,500 versus the prior year. These actions include our train length initiative, closing facilities in the coal network, consolidating a division headquarters and streamlining mechanical and operations that support functions. 
These actions, along with cycling the impact of winter weather last year, drove high efficiency gains in excess of $130 million seen here in the first quarter.  And for the full year, we now expect to deliver efficiency gains of around $250 million. 
Looking at labor and fringe we expect second quarter average headcount to stay relatively flat sequentially. We expect labor inflation to be around $25 million in the second quarter, in line with the levels seen here in the first quarter. 
Looking at MS&O expense, we expect inflation and the cycling of an operating property gain from last year to more than offset efficiency gains in volume-related savings. 
Fuel expense in the second quarter will be driven by lower cost per gallon, reflecting the current price environment, volume-related savings and continued focus on fuel efficiency. 
We expect depreciation in the second quarter to increase around $15 million versus the prior year, reflecting the ongoing investment in the business. 
Finally, equipment and other rents in the second quarter is expected to increase moderately from last year, with higher freight car rates and the increase in volume-related costs associated with automotive growth, more than offsetting improved car cycle times. 
Now let me wrap up from the next slide. CSX's first quarter results reflect challenging freight conditions with low commodity prices and the strong U.S. dollar continuing to impact most markets, resulting in a 5% volume decline this quarter. However, as we continue to reshape the company, our focus on pricing for the relative value of real service, driving efficiency gains and aligning resources to the softer demand environment helped to offset those volume headwinds. 
Looking ahead, we expect macroeconomic and coal headwinds to continued this year. Low commodity prices and the strength of the U.S. dollar are expected to continue impacting many of CSX's markets. 
In particular, we now expect total coal volume to decline around 25% for the full year. 
Looking at our expectations for the second quarter and full year. The impact of current market conditions on CSX's volume, particularly in coal is expected to outweigh the positive momentum we are seeing in service, which drives pricing efficiency and rightsizing initiatives. 
In the second quarter, we expect mid- to high-single-digit volume declines, with efficiency gain moderating from the level seen here in the first quarter. 
For the full year, in addition to liquidated damages we cycled during the first quarter, as we previously discussed, we will also be cycling a significant property transaction in the fourth quarter. 
As a result, we continue to expect second quarter and full year 2016 earnings per share to be down from last year. That said, we remain intensely focused on achieving strong pricing that reflects the value of CSX service product, rightsizing resources with lower demand and pursuing structural cost opportunities across the network. 
In particular, the aggressive cost actions we have taken over the last 12 months have helped to mitigate the challenging freight environment and weaker volumes. As a result of these initiatives, we now expect to deliver efficiency savings of around $250 million in 2016. 
With that, let me turn the the presentation back to Michael for his closing remarks.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Frank. As I think about CSX's first quarter performance, it's clear that the company's core earning power remained strong even in an environment in which macroeconomic forces are putting significant pressure on most of our markets. We know 2016
componenttext:
Thank you, Frank. As I think about CSX's first quarter performance, it's clear that the company's core earning power remained strong even in an environment in which macroeconomic forces are putting significant pressure on most of our markets. We know 2016 will be a challenging year, and we're focused on delivering the highest level of performance and results possible. 
In this environment, CSX continues to reshape its business and network for the economy of tomorrow. Maximizing growth opportunities and merchandise in Intermodal while also improving the profitability of this market to help offset the loss of coal. 
As we look forward, this team is resolute in its commitment to further transform today's company. 
The CSX of tomorrow is built on the strength of premier network, reaching diverse merchandise and Intermodal markets. It is focused on delivering service excellence for customers to support pricing that allows us to continue investing for the next generation to drive ever more efficient operations. And we will leverage technology to further improve safety, service and efficiency as we continue to evolve our business for the realities of tomorrow's economy. 
As we make decisions today to make that vision of tomorrow a reality, we remain focused on achieving a mid-60s operating ratio longer-term and delivering compelling value for you, our shareholders. 
Now we'll be glad to take your questions.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Ravi Shanker of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Ravi Shanker of Morgan Stanley.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a question on the productivity savings. Clearly, your first quarter performance was pretty amazing with a 133 compared to the full year run rate. You did bump up the full year by less than you kind of exceeded your prior guidance for 1Q. Can you just t
componenttext: So a question on the productivity savings. Clearly, your first quarter performance was pretty amazing with a 133 compared to the full year run rate. You did bump up the full year by less than you kind of exceeded your prior guidance for 1Q. Can you just talk about the cadence for the rest of the year and why that appears to step down so much versus the first quarter number?

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, this is Cindy. I think, we're off to a great start which reflects a lot of hard work by all our team to bring the $130 million productivity in the first quarter. And as I think about how 2015 progressed, we had a lot of initiatives that we started i
componenttext: Sure, this is Cindy. I think, we're off to a great start which reflects a lot of hard work by all our team to bring the $130 million productivity in the first quarter. And as I think about how 2015 progressed, we had a lot of initiatives that we started in the beginning of second quarter and on into the third quarter around rightsizing of our coal facilities as well as our train length initiative. So we'll be bumping up against those cost going forward. And also would say there was some benefit to a milder winter this year than what we had in 2015 in the first quarter. That said, we are never done in working on our productivity initiatives and the pace of change year has intensified accelerated, and we will continue to bring everything to the bottom line if we can. Keeping in mind that we have to balance that with serving our customers, and we won't compromise safety in that effort. And as we go forward, and you think about the run rate going forward of $40 million to $50 million in the next 3 quarters, that is higher than our historical run rate, with the exception of 2015 in terms of productivity that we'll be able to deliver. So if there's more to get, we will absolutely get it, and we'll be able to update you on that if we see that in future conversations, either in the quarterly or in Frank's roadshows.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's great color. If I can ask one question on coal. Just what's your outlook for the rest of the year? Obviously, you've given us your guidance but going into '17 and '18, just any new thoughts on the outlook for coal in the medium term?
componenttext: That's great color. If I can ask one question on coal. Just what's your outlook for the rest of the year? Obviously, you've given us your guidance but going into '17 and '18, just any new thoughts on the outlook for coal in the medium term?

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, this is Fredrik. So we guided you to about 25% down for the full year. We did on the domestic side here in the first quarter, did about 17 million tons and our view is as we think about the next couple of quarters, we like to think that we're going
componenttext: Sure, this is Fredrik. So we guided you to about 25% down for the full year. We did on the domestic side here in the first quarter, did about 17 million tons and our view is as we think about the next couple of quarters, we like to think that we're going to be at the -- maybe 17 million to 18 million tons range in the domestic side and and on the export side, we did almost 6 million tons in the first quarter. Traditionally, the first quarter is a little bit stronger than the other quarters. At least it's been like that last couple of years. We also enjoyed some spot moves here in the first quarter that we don't necessarily see in the remaining 3 quarters and may be a 4 million to 5 million tons a quarter on the export side. So that gives us that 22 million to 23 million range for coal guidance per quarter as we move through the year versus the 23 million tons we did in the first quarter.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ken Hoexter of Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ken Hoexter of Merrill Lynch.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to follow up on the employees. Great job on the larger-than-expected reduction, down 14%. But maybe if you walk us through why was the average cost per employee up last few quarters, I guess, we've seen it down 5% to 9%. This quarter, it was u
componenttext: Just wanted to follow up on the employees. Great job on the larger-than-expected reduction, down 14%. But maybe if you walk us through why was the average cost per employee up last few quarters, I guess, we've seen it down 5% to 9%. This quarter, it was up. Maybe you can talk a little bit about what's in that number, is there incentive comp or anything else that drives it. What should we look forward for that going forward?

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Ken, it's Fredrik. You're right. Headcount was down about 13%, 14%. While labor and fringe line was down about 9% or 10% so your comp per employee is about 4% to 5% higher. There's a couple of drivers. Some of those are industry related and some of t
componenttext: Hey, Ken, it's Fredrik. You're right. Headcount was down about 13%, 14%. While labor and fringe line was down about 9% or 10% so your comp per employee is about 4% to 5% higher. There's a couple of drivers. Some of those are industry related and some of those are CSX specific. Clearly, you have general wage inflation of 6%, 4% a year. And then what probably is the biggest driver for us is health and welfare inflation as the industry is reducing resources, you've got fewer employees to spread the health and welfare costs over. So both of those are industry in nature. In terms of maybe some CSX specific dynamics, as you furlough employee generally those are going to be are less tenured employees with lower all-in wages and then maybe as a last point, Ken, when you look at a year-over-year number of employees in training, they were significantly more employees in training in the year ago quarter than they are currently just given sort of where we are on the resource side and training pay is less than marked up pay. So You've got 3 or 4 moving parts in there that hopefully answers your question.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's does. Great follow-up, I'm sorry I missed David's comment to have one follow-up, or is it one question?
componenttext: That's does. Great follow-up, I'm sorry I missed David's comment to have one follow-up, or is it one question?

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So just on the coal market. Michael, can you look forward and tell us -- I know you talked in the past about matching Casper plant closing that were mandated '15 and '16. Is there something that now is done, and we should see that decelerate as you
componenttext: Okay. So just on the coal market. Michael, can you look forward and tell us -- I know you talked in the past about matching Casper plant closing that were mandated '15 and '16. Is there something that now is done, and we should see that decelerate as you look forward? I just want to say great answer by Fredrik in what we're seeing now, but I just want to understand is there something else that is going to continue to drive this? Is it just market dynamics as far as closings, or is there more that's going to structurally change the marketing and continue the pace we've seen in the decline?

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Ken, this is Fredrik. Frankly, based on is very low demand levels we seeing as we go through plant by plant and look at the closures that we expect to '16, '17 and '18, which covers all the announced closures that we have on a network, based on that
componenttext: Sure, Ken, this is Fredrik. Frankly, based on is very low demand levels we seeing as we go through plant by plant and look at the closures that we expect to '16, '17 and '18, which covers all the announced closures that we have on a network, based on that outlook that we have for the rest of the year now which are consistent with the guidance, there's only less than 1 million tons that we have in for those plants that have announced to close, which means that the closures side of things is really behind us to very large degree as we move forward because of the fact that the demand levels are so low.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Brandon Oglenski of Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Brandon Oglenski of Barclays.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016

componenttext: Difficult environment right now, but can you guys help us on the top line. As I know you've talked about mid- to high-volume decline for 2Q. But how do we think about contribution from price within the headwinds from mix? Does that get easier or more challenges as we progress through the year?

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Fredrik, again. Yes, the second quarter and probably even third quarter are going to be challenging quarter from a volume perspective. It's not really until we get to the fourth quarter where we'll have a little bit easier comparisons year-over-ye
componenttext: This is Fredrik, again. Yes, the second quarter and probably even third quarter are going to be challenging quarter from a volume perspective. It's not really until we get to the fourth quarter where we'll have a little bit easier comparisons year-over-year, both on the coal side and on the kind of general merchandise side as well. We are going to have a negative mix with us as long as our coal business is declining as fast as it is and our intermodal business is growing as fast as it is. Clearly, we are very transparent about what we're doing from a pricing perspective, and that's going to continue to be helpful as we move through the year.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, what I was getting it more from a top line perspective. Should we be thinking a similar outcome than what mix is? I guess, it's in the prepared remarks that mix might offset the favorable impact from pricing looking forward, and so top line can b
componenttext: I guess, what I was getting it more from a top line perspective. Should we be thinking a similar outcome than what mix is? I guess, it's in the prepared remarks that mix might offset the favorable impact from pricing looking forward, and so top line can be down a little bit more than volume?

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that as you try to model out what we're doing, we're kind of given you the individual components and the one piece that we haven't talked about is, of course, fuel as well. So you got to put those pieces together yourself. We're very explici
componenttext: Well, I think that as you try to model out what we're doing, we're kind of given you the individual components and the one piece that we haven't talked about is, of course, fuel as well. So you got to put those pieces together yourself. We're very explicit in terms of what we're seeing in each individual market. We certainly expect continued strong pricing as we move forward. And then of course, we have the variance of you fuel, whatever that is going to do.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Ossenbeck of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Ossenbeck of JPMorgan.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a quick question on just the impact of the dollar, the trade weighted index is about 5% off from the peak. You're still calling out some pretty negative headwinds from new term on commodity prices, but and experts and and on disruptive imports. Do you
componenttext: So a quick question on just the impact of the dollar, the trade weighted index is about 5% off from the peak. You're still calling out some pretty negative headwinds from new term on commodity prices, but and experts and and on disruptive imports. Do you think if it stays at this level, Fredrik, that you'll start to see some release towards the end of the year? Or do you think you need another 5% down moved to really get some relief in some of the these commodity markets?

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the dollars still well above kind of its 10-year average or so forth. But it's clear that it's been helpful in certain areas. The fact that it has taken a step back the last 2 months or so. One area where we had seen that is in the export coal side
componenttext: Well, the dollars still well above kind of its 10-year average or so forth. But it's clear that it's been helpful in certain areas. The fact that it has taken a step back the last 2 months or so. One area where we had seen that is in the export coal side on the metallurgical side with the benchmark actually has stepped up a little bit from, I think, the low point, $81 and Queensland Index to $84. And I think the bench or some of the spot moves are actually even higher than that at this point. And we're also seeing -- while it's not directly dollar-related, some of the potential tariff and kind of duties that we're seeing in a Metals business where you're starting to see drive down some of the imports to the country, which is starting -- slowly but surely, I think, heal our our Metals business as well. But it is fair to say that even with that sort of a relief over the last 2 months on the dollar, you are looking into the fourth quarter, I think, until you're going to start seeing meaningful improvements in the volume performance.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then on the productivity side. You mentioned that the train length initiative is approaching 1 year anniversary, so comps are going to get a little bit tougher. But maybe if you can just recap the last year, some of the accomplishments an
componenttext: Okay, great. And then on the productivity side. You mentioned that the train length initiative is approaching 1 year anniversary, so comps are going to get a little bit tougher. But maybe if you can just recap the last year, some of the accomplishments and what you think is reasonable in that context for some of the goals looking out through the rest of this year and into 2017.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Brian. Thanks. We, over the year, 2016 so 16% gains in our train lengths, and we're up to about 6,500 feet, 6,400 feet in total. We saw smallest incremental change in the fourth quarter as we had really large put in place all that we felt comfortabl
componenttext: Sure, Brian. Thanks. We, over the year, 2016 so 16% gains in our train lengths, and we're up to about 6,500 feet, 6,400 feet in total. We saw smallest incremental change in the fourth quarter as we had really large put in place all that we felt comfortably we could to maintain service to our customers, and we are bumping up against challenges. In the single track territory, we are citing little bit of the limit for us. Going forward, and then this year, we are planning to increase citing length in our corridor from Nashville to Cincinnati. That is presently limited to 6,500 feet, so we're making some structural adjustments to help us continue it, and we should see those investments in place and available to us in the back half of this year. So I would also say that one of the benefits of the initiative that we've seen is the ability to flex as seasonality impacts volume. So in summer months, we feel that we're a little bit less volume that's typically out there that we'll be able to continue to utilize train length in terms of reducing our cost, gives us ability that we haven't before. And certainly, if anything changes either up or down, we'll be able to adjust accordingly, to maintain train lengths. So we feel really good about the initiatives and our teams in the field has done a fantastic job putting it in place.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Chris Wetherbee of Citi.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Chris Wetherbee of Citi.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016

componenttext: Maybe a question for Cindy just following up on the productivity. When you think about increase from the 200 to 250, could maybe be done sort of the specific components a little bit to sort of looking at the puts and takes some of the expenses. I was just kind of curious kind of where that comes from, maybe how much is weather and how much is headcount. Wanted to get a sense there.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think a lot of that is the initiatives of the light of in place. I think the benefit to potentially go a little higher is to be able to continue to rightsize and streamline, which is a big part of our initiatives. So we've got technology and Micha
componenttext: Well, I think a lot of that is the initiatives of the light of in place. I think the benefit to potentially go a little higher is to be able to continue to rightsize and streamline, which is a big part of our initiatives. So we've got technology and Michael mentioned in his prepared remarks utilizing that in automation. So it will be some additional benefits to headcount, I believe.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay, that's helpful, I appreciate it. And then Fredrik maybe a question for you on the sort of the market outlook, I guess. Putting coal aside for a moment, it seems like we're still sort of maybe a bit weaker than seasonal expected at least as far
componenttext: Okay, okay, that's helpful, I appreciate it. And then Fredrik maybe a question for you on the sort of the market outlook, I guess. Putting coal aside for a moment, it seems like we're still sort of maybe a bit weaker than seasonal expected at least as far as the outlook for the second quarter. Just want to get a sense the last couple of weeks we've seen some challenges Intermodal sort of slipped back again. I just want to get a sense of kind of how you feel about where we stand with volumes, the economy just generally outside of some of the specific pressure points like coal.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean, taken to the highest level from what we see the economy at think we still see the overall economy progressing in that 2%, 2.5% range kind of an inspiring growth. Clearly, we're still dealing with after math that we saw last year both and ent
componenttext: Sure. I mean, taken to the highest level from what we see the economy at think we still see the overall economy progressing in that 2%, 2.5% range kind of an inspiring growth. Clearly, we're still dealing with after math that we saw last year both and entity side and also the strength of the dollar and the low commodity prices. And as I said earlier, that's going to be with us for at least another 2 quarters, and it's also why we guided to volumes to be down a little bit more year-over-year sequentially in the second quarter. Specifically, the last couple of weeks to your question, we look at our 4 key markets: Merchandise, intermodal, coal and auto. Our merchandise business has stayed probably some of the 2 strongest weak in the last 2 weeks but then we have seen some weakness in our coal markets, which is consistent with our guidance. We also had some operational issues with some of the terminals we served on the export side that impacted our volumes. Our auto business was very strong early on in March. We probably had 65% of our cars under load, and that's kind of cycling through that right now, but we continue to see good strength there for the rest of the year. And yes, we have seen a little bit of weakness in the intermodal space over the last few weeks, but I don't think anything has structurally changed there. So it's going to be tough second quarter, but I don't think it's a reflection of where the economy is heading or anything like that.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Tom Wadewitz of UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Tom Wadewitz of UBS.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to ask either Michael or Fredrik on pricing. You continue to get very good pricing in merchandise and intermodal. And then, I guess, the total is a bit less. How do you think that changes? Does that -- I mean, is that something kind of sustain thro
componenttext: Wanted to ask either Michael or Fredrik on pricing. You continue to get very good pricing in merchandise and intermodal. And then, I guess, the total is a bit less. How do you think that changes? Does that -- I mean, is that something kind of sustain through the full year? And is there a point where if you say rail traffic, you're saying's going to be weak for a couple quarters, is there does the same-store price are getting decelerate through the year, and it somewhat of a timing impacts? Or would you say, hey, look, we can just keep doing this, and we're kind of immune to softness in track, we're immune to excess or capacity. Just wonder if you could kind of talk about that. Because the numbers look pretty good -- are very good in intermodal and merchandise, but it just seems like there's a lot of excess capacity out there?

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we certainly not immune what's going on in the marketplace. And I think you've seen reflection of that here in the quarter versus the fourth quarter as you've seen a sequential down tick in our pricing. There, obviously, are specific drivers of that.
componenttext: Yes, we certainly not immune what's going on in the marketplace. And I think you've seen reflection of that here in the quarter versus the fourth quarter as you've seen a sequential down tick in our pricing. There, obviously, are specific drivers of that. We work with our customers on deal-by-deal basis to understand their needs and what opportunity to drive price is. Critical component of supporting our price right now is, of course, the fact that our service product has improved significantly. And I think our customers value a long-term access to our network in a market that we provide. Clearly, the market is softer now than it was a year ago. But yet, our pricing is frankly up year-over-year as well. And so we're going to work with our customers. Our price is going to reflect what the market allows us to do. At the same time, it's critical for us to be able to try. So we can reinvest in our business, and that's been a strategic imperative of ours for a long time. But underlying all the pricing is a service excellence for our customers.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I mean that hasn't been said, do you think it's more likely you're going to see stability through the year in your same-store price, or do you think there is some risk that you see deceleration in that as we look forward?
componenttext: So I mean that hasn't been said, do you think it's more likely you're going to see stability through the year in your same-store price, or do you think there is some risk that you see deceleration in that as we look forward?

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: We really don't forecast price. You'll have an opportunity to see price as we disclose our earnings each and every quarter. But strong pricing is important to what we're trying to do strategically, and we're going to work with our customers to make sure t
componenttext: We really don't forecast price. You'll have an opportunity to see price as we disclose our earnings each and every quarter. But strong pricing is important to what we're trying to do strategically, and we're going to work with our customers to make sure that they get the service that they need to be successful in their marketplace and at the same time, we need to be able to continue to reinvest in our business.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Do you just quick thought on export -- I'm sorry, where domestic coal inventories are?
componenttext: Okay. Do you just quick thought on export -- I'm sorry, where domestic coal inventories are?

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Domestic inventories are at very high levels. If you look at the north, it's well above 100, 112 days, I think, the latest data to we have in the set is even higher than that, about 170 days or so versus kind of a normal range of 55 to 70 days of bur
componenttext: Yes. Domestic inventories are at very high levels. If you look at the north, it's well above 100, 112 days, I think, the latest data to we have in the set is even higher than that, about 170 days or so versus kind of a normal range of 55 to 70 days of burn. And so we get plenty of inventory at our customers, which will take a fairly significant time, I think, to get down to more normalized levels. It's going to depend both and of course, where natural gas prices are, but also dependent on where we see the summary here in terms of how much burn we get as we've been move towards kind of a peaker and kind of that incremental demand levels we are even more weather-dependent than we've been in the past to try to work some of these stockpiles down.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Allison Landry of Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Allison Landry of Crédit Suisse.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016

componenttext: So following up on, I think, it was Ken's question earlier a lot the puts and takes on the labor line but as I think about total labor and French expense in the second quarter typically, we see a decline on a sequential basis. But should we think about it being roughly flat versus the first quarter or do you expect it to be a little bit higher?

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Allison, I think if you look at where we are an absolute headcount basis, what we guided to sequentially flat, which is down about the same percentage on a year-over-year basis that you saw in the first quarter. Clearly, the inflation will continue to imp
componenttext: Allison, I think if you look at where we are an absolute headcount basis, what we guided to sequentially flat, which is down about the same percentage on a year-over-year basis that you saw in the first quarter. Clearly, the inflation will continue to impact us with health and welfare piece there. So I'd say flat to up slightly probably will be the right thing to look at.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then thinking about the service metric and, in particular, train speed, it seems that CSX's lagging the other rails in terms of returning to levels seen in 2013. So is there anything specific driving this? And what would you expect to get
componenttext: Okay, great. And then thinking about the service metric and, in particular, train speed, it seems that CSX's lagging the other rails in terms of returning to levels seen in 2013. So is there anything specific driving this? And what would you expect to get back to peak productivity levels?

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Allison, when it comes to service, we're constantly working with Fredrik and his team in making sure we're not providing the service product that customers need,and we're never really satisfied with where we are. So the balancing act here is how to trade
componenttext: Allison, when it comes to service, we're constantly working with Fredrik and his team in making sure we're not providing the service product that customers need,and we're never really satisfied with where we are. So the balancing act here is how to trade that off with productivity and efficiency and make sure that -- back to Fredrik was talking about, we're earning the ability to your reinvest in our business. So I think when you look at it as to where we are, I alluded to a little bit earlier, we have some opportunities, we're seeing great performance in our double track territories. It's little bit more challenging in a single track territory, and we are making some investments to improve that in one of the core routes that we have between Nashville and Cincinnati. And we will continue to work on making adjustments as necessary to serve our customers well.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016

componenttext: And the train conditions it has some of the impact as well, right?

componenttext: That's what's driving the single-track challenge.

componenttext: Our next question comes from Rob Salmon of Deutsche Bank.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, following up with Tom's question. We're certainly think some really strong pricing across the overall network. If I look last quarter, the delta between the same-store sales pricing, which obviously includes coal and the merchandise intermodal, w
componenttext: I guess, following up with Tom's question. We're certainly think some really strong pricing across the overall network. If I look last quarter, the delta between the same-store sales pricing, which obviously includes coal and the merchandise intermodal, which kind of strippies it out expanded last quarter. Can you give us -- help us better understand what drove that. Was this kind of unique to the quarter, or should we -- or was there adjustments that were made across the network that are going to impact the duration of the year as well?

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Make sure I understand your question a little bit better, Rob?
componenttext: Make sure I understand your question a little bit better, Rob?

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I'm looking at kind of the delta between same-store sales at 3.1 and the core merchandise intermodal pricing at 4.0, it's about 90 basis points. If I look back to the fourth quarter, the split was about 40 basis points. Should I think about -- what dro
componenttext: If I'm looking at kind of the delta between same-store sales at 3.1 and the core merchandise intermodal pricing at 4.0, it's about 90 basis points. If I look back to the fourth quarter, the split was about 40 basis points. Should I think about -- what drove that kind of step up in that split last quarter? Was it something unique because of some closures or just how the volumes were coming on within intermodal -- sorry, within your coal network or were there underlying adjustments that we should be thinking about having an impact for the duration of the year as well?

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. The delta there is pretty much exclusively driven by the fact we have taken some pretty significant action in our export coal business. That is reflection of what the marketplace allows us to do or forces us to do right now to optimize our bottom li
componenttext: Sure. The delta there is pretty much exclusively driven by the fact we have taken some pretty significant action in our export coal business. That is reflection of what the marketplace allows us to do or forces us to do right now to optimize our bottom line. So that's really driven by export coal more than anything else. The fact that, that's spread has increased.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And so inherently, the guidance is export coal volumes coming down, so we should see less of a headwind as I look forward?
componenttext: Got it. And so inherently, the guidance is export coal volumes coming down, so we should see less of a headwind as I look forward?

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, that's one way of looking at it. That's probably -- yes, that's probably one way of looking at it.
componenttext: I guess, that's one way of looking at it. That's probably -- yes, that's probably one way of looking at it.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: That helps. And I guess also to get a little bit more call in terms of the intermodal RPU, the sequential decline, obviously, fuel had an impact there. But I would imagine the bigger impact in terms of the first quarter was just the declines -- the mix of
componenttext: That helps. And I guess also to get a little bit more call in terms of the intermodal RPU, the sequential decline, obviously, fuel had an impact there. But I would imagine the bigger impact in terms of the first quarter was just the declines -- the mix of the business with international being under so much pressure and the uptick in domestic. Was there any impact in terms of looser truckload market impacting intermodal RPU as well? Or were those 2 factors the entire explanation of the sequential decline here?

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Most of the impact were because of fuel. We also did see some mix impact in the quarter, in both international and in our domestic shorter length of haul that impacted as well. But most of our business intermodal space is on a long-term contracts. So
componenttext: Yes. Most of the impact were because of fuel. We also did see some mix impact in the quarter, in both international and in our domestic shorter length of haul that impacted as well. But most of our business intermodal space is on a long-term contracts. So while the spot market does affect a portion of the business. Most of it is really impacted by longer-term trends, not the shorter-term issues that we're facing. So while there was some challenges in the quarter, our pricing intermodal space is still positive.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Scott Group of Wolfe Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Scott Group of Wolfe Research.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'm not sure if you can help us kind of frame the earnings guidance a little bit better. I don't know if year-over-year is the right way to look at it, but if reported earnings were down 18% in the first quarter, are you expecting kind of similar decli
componenttext: So I'm not sure if you can help us kind of frame the earnings guidance a little bit better. I don't know if year-over-year is the right way to look at it, but if reported earnings were down 18% in the first quarter, are you expecting kind of similar declines in the second quarter, maybe less negative, more negative? And I know that you have tough comps on the liquidated damages, so maybe sequentially is the right way to think about it? I don't know if you can help kind of frame that guidance a little bit closer.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Scott, it's Frank. Yes, you're right. We did guide that the second quarter will be down on a year-over-year basis. You're also right that when you look at the second quarter of last year, it was an all-time record for us in terms of operating income,
componenttext: Hey, Scott, it's Frank. Yes, you're right. We did guide that the second quarter will be down on a year-over-year basis. You're also right that when you look at the second quarter of last year, it was an all-time record for us in terms of operating income, EPS and operating ratio. So we have a significant comp that we have to work through in the second quarter. We tried to give you as much granular guidance as we could as we look out over the next 3 months. Certainly, we gave you some very specific tonnage guidance around coal and then overall volumes in the mid- to high-single-digit range, just given the softness in the economy and certainly the coal headwinds play into that. And we're going to continue to focus on the things that we have the most impact on, certainly safety and service, productivities and you mentioned a run rate of 40 million to 50 million in the second quarter and improving service product as well as continued strong value pricing. So you add that all up and we come to a conclusion that earnings are going to down. If you want to talk sequentially generally speaking, second quarter earnings are better than first quarter earnings. If you just look historically at that.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I guess, what's tricky out of Europe in the past couple of years you've seen kind of significant increase I earnings first quarter to second quarter. If you go back further, it's more smaller increases in earnings, and I guess, we're  struggling with
componenttext: Yes, I guess, what's tricky out of Europe in the past couple of years you've seen kind of significant increase I earnings first quarter to second quarter. If you go back further, it's more smaller increases in earnings, and I guess, we're  struggling with the right way to think about the seasonality?

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, like I said, I think you'll see sequential earnings improvement. We have not sized that, but I think you see a typical seasonal pattern unless, of course, coal disappoints even further.
componenttext: Well, like I said, I think you'll see sequential earnings improvement. We have not sized that, but I think you see a typical seasonal pattern unless, of course, coal disappoints even further.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then just one quick follow up. So I think, one of the earlier questions you said that total labor cost should be kind of flattish 1Q to 2Q, but that implies like a 10% increase in comp per employee in the second quarter year-over-year. I just want to make sure that, that's right.

componenttext: No. I think what I was trying to do is to help Allison see that on a flat headcount number with the inflation that's fairly typical and a moderating productivity environment that it would be essentially flat to up a little bit. But again,...

componenttext: In terms of total labor?

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jason Seidl with Cowen & Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jason Seidl with Cowen & Company.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to think a little bit longer term here. Could you talk about rightsizing the network beyond just furloughs and repurposing maybe some locomotives. Where are you at in that stage? And what really can be done in some of the network that might just be
componenttext: I want to think a little bit longer term here. Could you talk about rightsizing the network beyond just furloughs and repurposing maybe some locomotives. Where are you at in that stage? And what really can be done in some of the network that might just be losing too much traffic for you?

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, if you indulge me a little bit here, Jason, I think the changes that we're making in our company are not short term reaction s to temporary economic conditions. So everything is on the table in terms of how we look at our networks. I think what you
componenttext: Well, if you indulge me a little bit here, Jason, I think the changes that we're making in our company are not short term reaction s to temporary economic conditions. So everything is on the table in terms of how we look at our networks. I think what you seen us do is rightsizing the coal field with some specific facilities reductions that we've made starting in the third quarter last year, which would be Erwin [indiscernible] We announced consolidation of the division in Huntington or from Huntington to other divisions and also reducing our yard operation and car operations in Russell, Kentucky. And the rest of our network, and we'll continue to work in a coal network and in the coalfields in making the right decisions, while still serving the customers that we have there. We look at the rest of the network, we're focusing very hard on density, which is part of our train length initiatives really kind of the underlying component of train lengths initiatives. So as we look at our main arteries, how can we continue to drive density there, which then allows us to streamline some facilities around that. So you've seen us do that with some of the mechanical reductions that we announced that we were going to make in some of our car facilities. And then going forward, too, beyond just simply network type of actions, our technology implementation that allows us to automate. So we're looking at this as the ability from my perspective to create a plan and execute a plan that helps CSX thrive in a rail industry that is fundamentally changing. And so we will continue to drive all of these initiatives and look for ways to tweak them to get even better efficiency, while still and I have to say it's very important to us that we serve our customers and have a service product that meets or exceeds expectations.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: So what you can do in the coal network done right now? Or is there more to come in terms of rightsizing that particular piece to your network?
componenttext: So what you can do in the coal network done right now? Or is there more to come in terms of rightsizing that particular piece to your network?

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say, we're never done in any of these. And we've taken some rarely large steps. We'll continue to look as the demand for our services changes, and it will change. We will take appropriate steps to take out the cost that need to come out. You have
componenttext: I would say, we're never done in any of these. And we've taken some rarely large steps. We'll continue to look as the demand for our services changes, and it will change. We will take appropriate steps to take out the cost that need to come out. You have also seen as, publicly put into the STD some discontinues of service on routes where the mines are shutdown, and we will continue to do those types, take those types of actions. But we'll be aggressive with it. But keeping in mind that it's a very profitable business for us, and we want to serve the customers that need our service.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Excuse me, you may want to mention the change in some of the pricing on the origin side.
componenttext: Excuse me, you may want to mention the change in some of the pricing on the origin side.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean obviously we work hand-in-hand with Cindy's team here to help hard, drive productivity not just in the coal fields but elsewhere in terms of train lengths initiative and so forth. But specific to Michael's point, we have changed the way we pr
componenttext: Sure. I mean obviously we work hand-in-hand with Cindy's team here to help hard, drive productivity not just in the coal fields but elsewhere in terms of train lengths initiative and so forth. But specific to Michael's point, we have changed the way we price our coal in the coal fields to drive efficiencies. So we've gone away from pricing zones, so to speak of rate districts towards specific point to point pricing that better reflects the reality of operating into certain brand line and so forth and the maintenance has to occur there, and we will price more efficient loading points differently going forward, which is tough discussions to have with our customers are the same time I think there's an understanding that this sort of a transformational change, you need to do something different. So there are a lot of things that we're doing cooperatively with Cindy to try to help drive out cost, but still protect our service going forward.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Guys, that's great color. I appreciate it. My follow up is on the intermodal side. Clearly, there's lack capacity in the truckload marketplace. In fact, you can argue it probably got more slack here in 1Q. When you talk to your Intermodal customers, how a
componenttext: Guys, that's great color. I appreciate it. My follow up is on the intermodal side. Clearly, there's lack capacity in the truckload marketplace. In fact, you can argue it probably got more slack here in 1Q. When you talk to your Intermodal customers, how are they viewing that? Are they viewing that slack capacity in the trucking market as just a temporary blip or maybe take advantage of it? Or are they viewing this longer term they want to play despot market maybe a little bit more than they have in the past?

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, as I said before that we have significant portion of our domestic business is on the long-term contracts. And I think those customers that participate there, and those products do value the long-term access to our network and the capabilities that we
componenttext: Yes, as I said before that we have significant portion of our domestic business is on the long-term contracts. And I think those customers that participate there, and those products do value the long-term access to our network and the capabilities that we provide. There's certainly, right now, excess capacity, which reflected in the spot pricing. I would say though that as we look at some of the underlying drivers there, especially new orders for tracks, which is coming down pretty rapidly, you still have the challenges in terms of driver retention and to escalating cost there, and we have probably the biggest impact that I think all of you have followed and recently followed as well is the ELDs next year and the impact that, that will have definitely as we get in the second half of 2017. So this is a soft environment and of that will be with us for a couple quarters. I think of an about us that we talked about for a long time is very much intact, and we're seeing that in a partnership with the truckers that we continue to build on to allow us to do the long-haul and then to do the pickup and then the delivery with we saw some of the strategic challenges. So it is softer, but we do think that's a temporary issue and that the basic thesis of our intermodal investments and our bullish investment long-term, to 9 million loads, et cetera, is very much intact. In the fact that we're get things still very much positive pricing in the intermodal space even in this environment right now I think bodes well for the long term prospect for our intermodal business.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Ben Hartford of Baird.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just taking the other side of the intermodal equation on the international side. Obviously, there's a lot of discussion with the implementation of solar and the the container rules. But any thought about how this going to look on the other side of 2016 an
componenttext: Just taking the other side of the intermodal equation on the international side. Obviously, there's a lot of discussion with the implementation of solar and the the container rules. But any thought about how this going to look on the other side of 2016 and longer term, if and when those rules are implemented?

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We are trying to understand that ourselves frankly. And I think we are learning from our customers. It could be opportunities for people shift earlier potentially. But at this point, I think it's a little unclear exactly what the impact will be.
componenttext: Yes. We are trying to understand that ourselves frankly. And I think we are learning from our customers. It could be opportunities for people shift earlier potentially. But at this point, I think it's a little unclear exactly what the impact will be.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jeff Kauffman of Buckingham Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jeff Kauffman of Buckingham Research.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question on efficiency has been asked but let me, Cindy, come back here a different way. Gross ton miles are down about 9% to 10%. Where are you right there in terms of locomotive capacity? Say, locomotives online, locomotives and storage? And I'm surp
componenttext: My question on efficiency has been asked but let me, Cindy, come back here a different way. Gross ton miles are down about 9% to 10%. Where are you right there in terms of locomotive capacity? Say, locomotives online, locomotives and storage? And I'm surprised I'm not seeing more production in cars online, kind of flat to down 1% over last year. Can you help explain to me some of these dynamics and what you can and can't do there?

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So let's talk about locomotives first. If you compare first quarter of '15 to this quarter, we actually have about 400 less locomotives active, which is about 10% in line with the volume reductions achieved that we talked about. Within that embedded
componenttext: Sure. So let's talk about locomotives first. If you compare first quarter of '15 to this quarter, we actually have about 400 less locomotives active, which is about 10% in line with the volume reductions achieved that we talked about. Within that embedded in that is the fact that we've got 275 store but there's also another 96 that are leased returns that will be returned in the second and third quarter of this year that we've already pulled out. So we feel like we're fairly decently in line with GTM reduction and our workload reduction and our resource take down a result of that. And it also allows us if we gets surprisingly upside, we have the ability to pull more locomotives out. And I would also add that we are receiving locomotives in our long-term purchase plan we received 26 locomotives of that 100 total in the first quarter. So that's kind of the puts and takes around locomotives, and we are very obviously focused on rightsizing our resources around both locomotives, employees and cars, and I'll talk about cars here as well. In terms of what you're seeing with cars online, we have about 1,300 cars stored right now versus our 13,000 stored right now versus 5,500 this time last year. When you look at cars online, the cars that are actually stored don't come out of the count for a fairly long period of time, about 36 months, it's a standard that we all have. So if you include this additional car that are pulled out in the first quarter, we're down about 4% in terms of cars online. If you take those out cars online number. So again, we feel like we're fairly well resourced appropriately for the demand that we have.

headline: CSX Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 13, 2016
