headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to follow up on Frank's comment on the increasing CapEx and accelerating locomotives purchasing. Just wondering, why you're accelerating the CapEx. Did you get better pricing on equipment? And does that change your thoughts on cash flow buybac
componenttext: Just wanted to follow up on Frank's comment on the increasing CapEx and accelerating locomotives purchasing. Just wondering, why you're accelerating the CapEx. Did you get better pricing on equipment? And does that change your thoughts on cash flow buybacks and use of capital as we move forward?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Honestly, it was the avoidance of seller financing charges that we would've incurred if we had stuck with the original deal to pay off the engines next year. So it's just the timing over a couple of months. No impact on cash flow, it's kind of a one-time
componenttext: Honestly, it was the avoidance of seller financing charges that we would've incurred if we had stuck with the original deal to pay off the engines next year. So it's just the timing over a couple of months. No impact on cash flow, it's kind of a one-time thing switch between 2017 and 2016.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it's not a commentary on what you thought on pace of volumes or anything else, just financing to accelerate in a declining volume environment?
componenttext: So it's not a commentary on what you thought on pace of volumes or anything else, just financing to accelerate in a declining volume environment?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we either pay the financing charges or avoid them by pulling it forward. And as Cindy is mentioning, every dollar's on the table and that seem like a good way to save a little bit of money as we look forward into 2017.
componenttext: Well, we either pay the financing charges or avoid them by pulling it forward. And as Cindy is mentioning, every dollar's on the table and that seem like a good way to save a little bit of money as we look forward into 2017.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Brandon Oglenski of Barclays.
componenttext: The next question comes from Brandon Oglenski of Barclays.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I want to follow up from Ken's question on CapEx. So you talked about the ability in 2017 to get back towards a core investment around 16% to 17% of revenue. But I'm assuming that excludes spending on things like PTC. So you might not be willing to tel
componenttext: So I want to follow up from Ken's question on CapEx. So you talked about the ability in 2017 to get back towards a core investment around 16% to 17% of revenue. But I'm assuming that excludes spending on things like PTC. So you might not be willing to tell us right know what you think the noncore items might be in '17, but maybe if you could give us some context on what noncore investments has been for the past couple of years?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, so the only thing that we exclude from core investment is Positive Train Control. If you look at what we're doing this year, our all-in number of 2.7 has the $300 million increase for the engines that I just mentioned. It has $300 million for Positi
componenttext: Sure, so the only thing that we exclude from core investment is Positive Train Control. If you look at what we're doing this year, our all-in number of 2.7 has the $300 million increase for the engines that I just mentioned. It has $300 million for Positive Train Control, which gets you down to the $2.1 billion of core capital that we have started the year talking about. And as you might remember, that was a decline of over $100 million in core capital from 2015. You'll continue to see us focus hard on core capital and making sure that we're making the right decisions in terms of infrastructure, equipment and return-seeking investments. As you think about PTC going into 2017, that number should decline some from the levels that you see here in 2016, it should step down a little bit, and then again, between '17 and '18 as we set our sights towards being compliant with the FRA's and Congress's mandate that will be hardware complete by the end of 2018. And then it should lag down even further between '17 -- excuse me, '18 and '19. And then hopefully all of that will go away as we get to full implementation in 2020. And then you won't see us carry a Positive Train Control CapEx line after that. It will just become embedded with broader capital plan.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Brian Ossenbeck of JPMorgan Chase.
componenttext: The next question comes from Brian Ossenbeck of JPMorgan Chase.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you can give us an update on the CCX projects. When you talk about CapEx, what type of CapEx are you expecting there? Is there something we can do public, private partnership? And how close are you to scoping out and finding a site for
componenttext: I was wondering if you can give us an update on the CCX projects. When you talk about CapEx, what type of CapEx are you expecting there? Is there something we can do public, private partnership? And how close are you to scoping out and finding a site for that investment?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Michael. We're very excited about the CCX opportunity. We find that we're getting great cooperation from the state and local officials. We're very encouraged that we will be able to work cooperatively with them. As you mentioned, as a public-priva
componenttext: This is Michael. We're very excited about the CCX opportunity. We find that we're getting great cooperation from the state and local officials. We're very encouraged that we will be able to work cooperatively with them. As you mentioned, as a public-private partnership with the state providing about half of the funds and us providing the other half of the funds. And we think it's going to be a tremendous economic development opportunity for the State of North Carolina. We're excited about the progress we're making on it. The exact location hasn't been finally determined at this point but we're continuing to make good progress.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Can you just remind me of the timing and the size of the expense?
componenttext: Okay. Can you just remind me of the timing and the size of the expense?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's going to be roughly $150 million of ours [ph], which is it part of the long-term capital plan that Frank evaluated, and the state is putting up close to a similar amount for the facility.
componenttext: It's going to be roughly $150 million of ours [ph], which is it part of the long-term capital plan that Frank evaluated, and the state is putting up close to a similar amount for the facility.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Allison Landry of Credit Suisse.
componenttext: The next question comes from Allison Landry of Credit Suisse.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about mix during the quarter? In particular, it looks like maybe there were some positive mix within the coal segment. So I just wanted to see if you could help us understand if that was on the domestic side
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about mix during the quarter? In particular, it looks like maybe there were some positive mix within the coal segment. So I just wanted to see if you could help us understand if that was on the domestic side or export? What drove that? And if that's something we should expect to persist in the third quarter?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Allison, on the coal, our view specifically, we did have some positive mix. Obviously, we also had the help of our fixed variable contracts and continued pricing on the domestic side. Offsetting that is of course fuel surcharge revenue coming down
componenttext: Yes. So Allison, on the coal, our view specifically, we did have some positive mix. Obviously, we also had the help of our fixed variable contracts and continued pricing on the domestic side. Offsetting that is of course fuel surcharge revenue coming down and then the actions that we've taken on the export coal market. I do think that it changes quarter-by-quarter, but it is a sustainable level, and there will be quarters when they will be up, and there will be quarters when down. The focus on our part is to make sure that we continue to do core pricing appropriately, and then let fuel mix fall wherever it's going to fall.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And were there any contracts on the domestic side that came up for renewal in the second quarter that maybe boosted that a little bit?
componenttext: Okay. And were there any contracts on the domestic side that came up for renewal in the second quarter that maybe boosted that a little bit?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nothing specifically. We have about a quarter [ph], 20% to 25% of our contract coming up here by the end of the year. But nothing specifically here in the second quarter that would have changed the RPU number.
componenttext: Nothing specifically. We have about a quarter [ph], 20% to 25% of our contract coming up here by the end of the year. But nothing specifically here in the second quarter that would have changed the RPU number.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Chris Wetherbee of Citi.
componenttext: The next question comes from Chris Wetherbee of Citi.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to follow up on the CapEx side and just kind of talk a little bit about locomotives spend. You pulled some forward into 2016. How should we think about the change in locomotives spend as we go into 2017 and 2018?
componenttext: Wanted to follow up on the CapEx side and just kind of talk a little bit about locomotives spend. You pulled some forward into 2016. How should we think about the change in locomotives spend as we go into 2017 and 2018?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So if you take just a year or 2 view of that, and you look at where we are from a locomotive storage perspective, we got about 350 engines in storage. And then as you look towards the back half of the year, as Cindy gets the deliveries of about 60,
componenttext: Sure. So if you take just a year or 2 view of that, and you look at where we are from a locomotive storage perspective, we got about 350 engines in storage. And then as you look towards the back half of the year, as Cindy gets the deliveries of about 60, 65 of the remaining engines from the purchase commitment that we had started in 2014, I think you should expect in the volume environment that we'll continue to store engines through that period. As you look forward into '17 and '18, assuming volume stay essentially where they are, I doubt you would see us in the market for new locomotives. At the same time, we do believe that continuing to reinvest in our 4 axle or our yard and switcher engines is the long-term right thing to do, so you might see a little bit of capital going toward rebuilding the 4 axle engines. But again, probably no big purchases in the period. Cindy anything want to add to that?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I would say, as we look ahead in the engines that we have stored, the 350 that Frank mentions are readily bale to be brought back to service if we need them. In addition to that, we have, as we've taken locomotives out this year, some have gone into r
componenttext: No, I would say, as we look ahead in the engines that we have stored, the 350 that Frank mentions are readily bale to be brought back to service if we need them. In addition to that, we have, as we've taken locomotives out this year, some have gone into recommended retire status, which would not be in that stored count. So when you look at GTM's down about 10%. Our active fleet is also down about 10%. And going forward, I would echo Frank's comments.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: So is that the right way to think about it on a GTM basis? I guess it's a tough question because it's mixed, but when you think about potential volume growth, how much latent capacity do you have on the locomotives side for the next year or 2? Is it rough
componenttext: So is that the right way to think about it on a GTM basis? I guess it's a tough question because it's mixed, but when you think about potential volume growth, how much latent capacity do you have on the locomotives side for the next year or 2? Is it roughly 10% when you think about it in GTM terms?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: When I think about it, GTM total [ph], when you think about our workload demands, but we're obviously cycling a very different type of commodity mix with coal being reduced in lesser GTM-intensive business growing hopefully. So we will look at GTM in term
componenttext: When I think about it, GTM total [ph], when you think about our workload demands, but we're obviously cycling a very different type of commodity mix with coal being reduced in lesser GTM-intensive business growing hopefully. So we will look at GTM in terms of workload. But when I think about what's available to bring back, it's really in what's our stored status, not in the total that we have taken out this year. We're going to recommend to retire some of the locomotives that we've taken out this year, and there's also leases that we've returned too, I might add.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, so probably a little less than that number, I guess, ultimately, is what you're saying?
componenttext: Okay, so probably a little less than that number, I guess, ultimately, is what you're saying?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Less than 10% is what's available to bring back.
componenttext: Less than 10% is what's available to bring back.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Tom Wadewitz of UBS.
componenttext: The next question comes from Tom Wadewitz of UBS.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to ask a question, I think it's for Fredrik, it's on the domestic intermodal side. You guys have done a good job of realizing volume growth despite a difficult market, difficult backdrop in prod. I think you're up 5% in second quarter domestic inte
componenttext: Wanted to ask a question, I think it's for Fredrik, it's on the domestic intermodal side. You guys have done a good job of realizing volume growth despite a difficult market, difficult backdrop in prod. I think you're up 5% in second quarter domestic intermodal, but then you're saying flat in third. Is that just kind of impact from that 1 contract? Or is there some slowing that you're seeing in the market? So I just wonder if you could talk on the domestic intermodal?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Tom. No, it really is impact from the fact that last year in the third quarter we had a significant ramp up in our domestic intermodal business. And as we move in here to the third quarter, we're going to start lapping that which is going to make th
componenttext: Sure, Tom. No, it really is impact from the fact that last year in the third quarter we had a significant ramp up in our domestic intermodal business. And as we move in here to the third quarter, we're going to start lapping that which is going to make the volume comparison a lot more difficult than it's been the first part of the year. And that's really the key driver. The market out there is obviously -- it continues to be challenge with a fair amount of excess capacity. From our perspective though, the intermodal story is broader than that, and we continue to have good success in converting traffic off from the highway in partnership with the trucking industry. And we also continue to get some pricing even in this tough environment which is -- bodes well for the long term.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you have any thoughts on inventories and whether high inventories are coming down somewhat? Or is that still an issue that you hear from shippers?
componenttext: Do you have any thoughts on inventories and whether high inventories are coming down somewhat? Or is that still an issue that you hear from shippers?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Inventory is still at the high level. It's been a sequential decline just a little bit, but it's still high versus historical basis. So that's certainly impacting the international part of our intermodal business, more perhaps than it does on the domestic
componenttext: Inventory is still at the high level. It's been a sequential decline just a little bit, but it's still high versus historical basis. So that's certainly impacting the international part of our intermodal business, more perhaps than it does on the domestic side, which is also why you're seeing the steamship line continuing to struggle quite significant, and demand on that side is very weak at the moment.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Jeff Kauffman of Buckingham Research.
componenttext: The next question comes from Jeff Kauffman of Buckingham Research.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Question for Frank. Frank, there's been a lot asked about the CapEx and I understand what you're doing in the locomotive CapEx. But that is going to create a little bit more of a cash shortfall. Since it's just really borrowing from '17, do we fund that s
componenttext: Question for Frank. Frank, there's been a lot asked about the CapEx and I understand what you're doing in the locomotive CapEx. But that is going to create a little bit more of a cash shortfall. Since it's just really borrowing from '17, do we fund that shortfall with debt and continue repurchasing shares at these levels? Or do we focus on maintaining cash and maybe slow the repurchase until cash flow gets a little bigger next year?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jeff. In terms of buybacks, you know we're in the midst of the 2 year $2 billion program that we announced in April of last year. You've seen us essentially ratably buy throughout the period about $1.2 billion that we've repurchased so far through
componenttext: Thanks, Jeff. In terms of buybacks, you know we're in the midst of the 2 year $2 billion program that we announced in April of last year. You've seen us essentially ratably buy throughout the period about $1.2 billion that we've repurchased so far throughout that program, about $800 million-or-so left. I think absent the recession, you should see us continue to do that ratably from now through the end of the first quarter of next year. And then reevaluate where we are from a cash and a ratings perspective as well as what the forward view of earnings might be at that time.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: And 1 detail follow-up. You never mentioned, what are coal inventory days in your northern and southern service regions?
componenttext: And 1 detail follow-up. You never mentioned, what are coal inventory days in your northern and southern service regions?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So right now, where we are, we are in the south -- we use an external source for this, we're at about 98 days on forward burn in the south, and about 71 in the north. And just to give you kind of the average benchmark, I think we've given the past,
componenttext: Sure. So right now, where we are, we are in the south -- we use an external source for this, we're at about 98 days on forward burn in the south, and about 71 in the north. And just to give you kind of the average benchmark, I think we've given the past, in the south, we expect the average to be about 70, and in the north, 55. So whether you look at days burn or tons, we're up about 5% year-over-year using that same source. So we're still the pretty elevated level as we sit here today. Clearly the warm weather is helping, but it's highly unlikely that by the end of the year, we'll get to normalized levels is our best prediction at this point.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Scott Group of Wolfe Research.
componenttext: The next question comes from Scott Group of Wolfe Research.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: So wanted to ask one more on the CapEx. If we're not signing locomotives for a few years and PTC spending starting to come down, it feels like, just given volume would maybe, just growth CapEx, in general, should be coming down. I would think that there's
componenttext: So wanted to ask one more on the CapEx. If we're not signing locomotives for a few years and PTC spending starting to come down, it feels like, just given volume would maybe, just growth CapEx, in general, should be coming down. I would think that there's an opportunity to cut the CapEx kind of below that historical 15% to 17% of revenue, then you guys can really get good free cash flow story going with your -- I think, with probably help the multiple here. How do you think about that? And is that a realistic opportunity?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, it's Frank. Certainly, we're in our planning process for 2017. It's really too early for us to comment on what we think next year's core CapEx is going to be. I think what you're hearing us say is that we're committed to returning to that about 16%
componenttext: Scott, it's Frank. Certainly, we're in our planning process for 2017. It's really too early for us to comment on what we think next year's core CapEx is going to be. I think what you're hearing us say is that we're committed to returning to that about 16% to 17% of revenue from a CapEx perspective within that in any given year, there's going to be differences between how much is in infrastructure, how much is in equipment, how much is in returns-seeking investment. And as I think I've mentioned in the conferences back in June, we're also committed to making sure that the CSX of Tomorrow initiatives are part of that capital guidance. So it's not something that you're going to see us take that guidance up because of the CSX of Tomorrow initiative. We think all the right trade-offs within that framework in order to be able to deliver on the CSX of Tomorrow, which is a very important part of our future, as Michael mentioned in his remarks.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess I'm just thinking, if historically about 16% to 17% of revenue historically has included locomotives, so if we're not buying as many locomotives, I would think that there's an opportunity to get below that historical level? Is that realistic? Or a
componenttext: I guess I'm just thinking, if historically about 16% to 17% of revenue historically has included locomotives, so if we're not buying as many locomotives, I would think that there's an opportunity to get below that historical level? Is that realistic? Or are you saying not?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not commenting one way or another. To be honest, Scott, I'm telling that we'll give you some guidance in 2017 as we get closer to the end of the year. And then as we begin to talk about the CSX of Tomorrow in the associated financial parameters of tha
componenttext: I'm not commenting one way or another. To be honest, Scott, I'm telling that we'll give you some guidance in 2017 as we get closer to the end of the year. And then as we begin to talk about the CSX of Tomorrow in the associated financial parameters of that, we'll give you some guidance longer term.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if I could just ask one more, just kind of a detailed question. Just on coal, can you give us the mix of your coal by basin, at coal, PRV and where you see the switching points?
componenttext: Okay. And if I could just ask one more, just kind of a detailed question. Just on coal, can you give us the mix of your coal by basin, at coal, PRV and where you see the switching points?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So here in the second quarter, we saw an increase in our basin coal up to about 37% of our overall utility portfolio. And really, that's what's relevant, I think just looking at the utility portfolio. So 37% thereabouts was Illinois, PRB about 20. S
componenttext: Sure. So here in the second quarter, we saw an increase in our basin coal up to about 37% of our overall utility portfolio. And really, that's what's relevant, I think just looking at the utility portfolio. So 37% thereabouts was Illinois, PRB about 20. So we had about 57% of our coal was in Illinois basin, Powder Basin, and the rest was Appalachia. And that is up a little bit from what we saw in the first quarter. And frankly, we expect Illinois Basin to continue to do well longer term as part of our utility mix.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Jason Seidl from Cowen.
componenttext: The next question comes from Jason Seidl from Cowen.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to focus a little bit on the mineral line. Obviously, the new fly ash contract is ramping up, and that's distorting the yields a little bit here. How should we look at yields going forward for the remainder of the year as the contract ramps up?
componenttext: Wanted to focus a little bit on the mineral line. Obviously, the new fly ash contract is ramping up, and that's distorting the yields a little bit here. How should we look at yields going forward for the remainder of the year as the contract ramps up?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're talking about yields overall or specifically in minerals?
componenttext: You're talking about yields overall or specifically in minerals?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Specifically, in minerals.
componenttext: Specifically, in minerals.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, overall, it's -- I don't think you're going to see a much different picture in terms of the yields. Clearly, the fly ash is a big initiative on our side. We're also seeing strength in other parts of our minerals business. But I don't think you --
componenttext: I think, overall, it's -- I don't think you're going to see a much different picture in terms of the yields. Clearly, the fly ash is a big initiative on our side. We're also seeing strength in other parts of our minerals business. But I don't think you -- that, that our view is significantly different than any other part of our minerals business. So I think those drivers are similar within the other parts of that portfolio as well.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just a follow-up question on coal. You guys talked about being 98 days in the south, 71 days in the north. How should we think about burning that's through? If we get sort of a normalized summer and a normal winter, at what point are we going to
componenttext: Okay. And just a follow-up question on coal. You guys talked about being 98 days in the south, 71 days in the north. How should we think about burning that's through? If we get sort of a normalized summer and a normal winter, at what point are we going to get back to sort of that -- those levels you talked about, 70 in the south and 55 in the north?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, most of the external sources we use and also discussions with utilities would indicate on average that we'll get there sometime in 2017. Hopefully, in the first part of 2017. Clearly, as I said earlier, that this summer is helping. Clearly, there ar
componenttext: Well, most of the external sources we use and also discussions with utilities would indicate on average that we'll get there sometime in 2017. Hopefully, in the first part of 2017. Clearly, as I said earlier, that this summer is helping. Clearly, there are utilities that are below where they want to be. And frankly, we have seen additional calls here over the last month or so. That's a pretty low bar because the phones certainly wasn't ringing for several months. But it is helping, but you have some of our utilities that we serve have an awful lot of coal on the ground at this point, and it's going to take more than just a really hot summer to get it back to where it needs on average.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so as we think about coal for next year, I'm assuming we should think at least the first half should be still continue to be pressure?
componenttext: And so as we think about coal for next year, I'm assuming we should think at least the first half should be still continue to be pressure?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that there is a high likelihood of that. I used to say, we will have a much better feel for that as we get through here this summer to see where we end up. Usually, not just in coal but in all of our markets we go out and work closely with our cus
componenttext: I think that there is a high likelihood of that. I used to say, we will have a much better feel for that as we get through here this summer to see where we end up. Usually, not just in coal but in all of our markets we go out and work closely with our customers to get a sense of what the plan for '17 should look like. And at that point, as we get into third quarter and definitely the fourth quarter, we have a much better sense of where we are. But overall, I think it's important to say 2 things: One, what's happening here right now in coal in terms of the hot weather and the fact the natural gas price have recovered a little bit is really more of an impact for '17 than this short term in '16. And then I think it's also important, we've been probably the most vocal on this, from our perspective right now, we're planning for a sector decline in our coal business. We would love to be wrong about that, but in terms of how we approach our business and how we approach our planning, we continue to see as sector decline. It doesn't mean that you can't have a year or so where it goes up, but overall, we think that the trend is pretty clear where it's heading.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Ben Hartford of Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: The next question comes from Ben Hartford of Robert W. Baird.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Cindy, just some perspective on current service levels kind of picked your measure, whether it's realtime or velocity. Those measures have somewhat stagnated over the past few quarters, still above 2013's peak level. Any thought or hope of being able to r
componenttext: Cindy, just some perspective on current service levels kind of picked your measure, whether it's realtime or velocity. Those measures have somewhat stagnated over the past few quarters, still above 2013's peak level. Any thought or hope of being able to return those measures back to 2013 levels? Or should we, for the time being, kind of ignore what you're able to do in '13 and look for improvement, but the likelihood of returning those levels are low. I'd be interested in any perspective there?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Well, we have improved our service levels both sequentially and year-over-year, as you can see from the charts. We are actually a little ahead of where we had planned to be for this year. And obviously, improved network performance does provide som
componenttext: Great. Well, we have improved our service levels both sequentially and year-over-year, as you can see from the charts. We are actually a little ahead of where we had planned to be for this year. And obviously, improved network performance does provide some efficiency gains for us. And we want -- we are committed to provide a service product that meets or exceeds our customer's expectations, helps Frederik price for the value of the service that we provide. We have to balance that always with some efficiency initiatives, and I think we're doing that. I think we are pretty happy with where we are. Where there's always opportunity to improve, and we will do that. I think I've also highlighted before, and you've probably heard Frank talk about it before, where we've installed our train length initiative that is more problematic for us in terms of the velocity, let's say, is on the southern part of our network, which is mostly singletrack. So we think that's the right mix. We've made the right decision there. We are seeing over time down, recruise down and other measures that give us confidence that we are improving. But I think we're pleased with where we are, and we will work to improve. And Frank?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: And let me just speak from a sales and marketing perspective. I would say that the efforts this year has been to really focus on the most service-sensitive part of our business, specifically intermodal business, to drive that service up, and that's where
componenttext: And let me just speak from a sales and marketing perspective. I would say that the efforts this year has been to really focus on the most service-sensitive part of our business, specifically intermodal business, to drive that service up, and that's where we made the most gains. And it is markedly different, and it's really helping our pricing efforts. Also one of the key things for us is to reduce the span around the mean, and that is also improving significantly. Because as also, as we look at the broader portfolio, it is -- by being able to be there each and every day at a reliable way, our local services has improved significantly as well. And really as we look at the customer-facing measurements, not so much the measurements that you're seeing in terms of what we've disclosed externally, has improved significantly as well. So from our perspective, I think we're making that right trade-offs between productivity and service. And as Cindy says on the productivity side, we're never done. And the same thing holds true on the service side, we always want to do better for our customers, and I think we're seeing that cooperations from operations, and we feel very good about where we are.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: That make sense. So from the metrics that we can see, that 2013 high watermark, are those targets there credible? Do you feel like you can get back to those levels over time or potential exceeded them?
componenttext: That make sense. So from the metrics that we can see, that 2013 high watermark, are those targets there credible? Do you feel like you can get back to those levels over time or potential exceeded them?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think everything is on the table. In terms of the pace and cadence of which we may get there, it's probably a longer term type of aspiration. But again, there's nothing that we're satisfied with. I'm not satisfied with the service measurements nor the e
componenttext: I think everything is on the table. In terms of the pace and cadence of which we may get there, it's probably a longer term type of aspiration. But again, there's nothing that we're satisfied with. I'm not satisfied with the service measurements nor the efficiencies, and we will continue to work on both, but I think that's a longer-term initiative.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Cheril Radbourne of TD Securities.
componenttext: The next question comes from Cheril Radbourne of TD Securities.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to ask a question on productivity, which I think was a highlight again this quarter. And you always do a very good job of disclosing productivity versus the volume-related costs reductions. I just wonder if you could talk about the rigor with which
componenttext: Wanted to ask a question on productivity, which I think was a highlight again this quarter. And you always do a very good job of disclosing productivity versus the volume-related costs reductions. I just wonder if you could talk about the rigor with which you track that internally and make sure that you're holding people accountable?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Frank, and absolutely we have a lot of rigor within the finance organization, which, in some respects, is the score keeper here. What we do in terms of tracking productivity, we make sure that we normalize for volume first. So to the extent that ther
componenttext: It's Frank, and absolutely we have a lot of rigor within the finance organization, which, in some respects, is the score keeper here. What we do in terms of tracking productivity, we make sure that we normalize for volume first. So to the extent that there are volume-variable expenses, then those don't count toward productivity. And what you've seen this year is that in the first half, we're about $150 million of what we call rightsizing or volume-variable cost reductions, and then $230 million of structural cost efficiencies. There is a lot of accountability around productivity, and again, that is the way that we take cost out long term. Let me give you just a simplistic example that may help illustrate it. If so -- let's use coal just because coal volumes have come down. So if a coal train ran last year but doesn't run this year, then the cost associated with locomotives and crudes and fuel and car costs would come out of volume variable expenses, and so you'd hear us talk about those in terms of rightsizing. If, for example, and we have instances of this where you have 2 coal trains that ran last year and this year through the train length initiative and that we're outing, we've actually put those 2 trains together and run a 200-car trains to 100-car trains, the efficiencies associated with less locomotive-intensity, crew-intensity, fuel-intensity, et cetera, would be allocated toward productivity.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from David Vernon of Bernstein.
componenttext: The next question comes from David Vernon of Bernstein.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Frank, this is kind of a great set up to what I wanted to ask you in terms of the size of the absolute productivity number. As we've gotten through the year, it does seem like that number is growing at the same time that our expectations for  volume are g
componenttext: Frank, this is kind of a great set up to what I wanted to ask you in terms of the size of the absolute productivity number. As we've gotten through the year, it does seem like that number is growing at the same time that our expectations for  volume are getting worse. Is it right to believe that you guys are finding more opportunities to drive that productivity because there's less traffic on the network and that the productivity pool is kind of expanding in relation to the bottom decline? That's kind of the first question I wanted to ask you.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think what you'll see us do in an environment like this, when we realized that the revenue portfolio is in transition and the volume, especially on the coal side, is coming down, is we turned over every rock. And you heard Cindy talk a lot about all the
componenttext: I think what you'll see us do in an environment like this, when we realized that the revenue portfolio is in transition and the volume, especially on the coal side, is coming down, is we turned over every rock. And you heard Cindy talk a lot about all the things that she's doing on the operating side and not to exclude the G&A side. I mean, the G&A side, every department is also looking for ways to challenge every cost dollars, so I think what you're doing -- what you're seeing is really an j across-the-board focus on our company to be disciplined on cost. We've always been disciplined on cost, we've always tried to offset inflation with productivity, which is, given where we know the business is going, we're really looking at the structural things in a way to reduce the overall cost intensity of the business. And when volumes inflect postively, obviously, we'll be able grow with that both on the earnings and the margin side.  And to the extent the growth comes in the best merchandise business or the intermodal business or the automotive business, you should see us grow with the incremental margins. So I think what you're seeing is the company focused on cost given the environment.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I guess, and then the second part of the question is, as you're sort of taking that, in your example, the 2 100-car trains and make it a 200-car train, I guess, when volume does inflect, how do you think the cost structure will react? Do you think tha
componenttext: And I guess, and then the second part of the question is, as you're sort of taking that, in your example, the 2 100-car trains and make it a 200-car train, I guess, when volume does inflect, how do you think the cost structure will react? Do you think that the variable cost might go up, and you should probably just shouldn't care because the contribution is so high? Or do you think you can actually sustain this lower level of variable unit cost that you've been able to engineer given the extra space on the network?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, it depends in large part on how the volumes come back and where the volumes come back. We have engineered a lot of flexibility into the network through the train length and variable scheduling initiatives that you've heard us talk about. Again, as I
componenttext: Sure, it depends in large part on how the volumes come back and where the volumes come back. We have engineered a lot of flexibility into the network through the train length and variable scheduling initiatives that you've heard us talk about. Again, as I mentioned, if volumes come back in class traffic and part of the scheduled network, you should see us be able to grow volumes without adding back variable cost. If the volumes come back in bulk traffic where you're adding a new train start for a new bulk train, then you should see us bring that back. But again, the resource is back, but again, that would be a nice margin so you would want us to do that.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes -- no, that's kind of what it seems like.
componenttext: Yes -- no, that's kind of what it seems like.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from John Larkin of Stifel.
componenttext: The next question comes from John Larkin of Stifel.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to see how much granularity on the accelerated productivity targets you're willing to share with us. There were a lot of initiatives obviously under way: Coal network rationalization, longer trains, closing down some excess facilities, elimina
componenttext: Just wanted to see how much granularity on the accelerated productivity targets you're willing to share with us. There were a lot of initiatives obviously under way: Coal network rationalization, longer trains, closing down some excess facilities, eliminating difficult overhead. All of those are very admirable initiatives. Are there any 2 or 3 of those that have really been the primary reason why you've almost achieved your entire former productivity target in the first 6 months that have originally been established for the entire year?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think some of what we've been able to is put a series of initiatives together, mostly structural. With the closure of facilities late last year and the coal network and moving forward into this year where we also closed roughly yard and also consolidate
componenttext: I think some of what we've been able to is put a series of initiatives together, mostly structural. With the closure of facilities late last year and the coal network and moving forward into this year where we also closed roughly yard and also consolidated our Huntington Division headquarters. But it's not just in the coal space. We've also announced publicly and probably consolidated facilities in Central Florida with Winston Yard in Tampa, consolidation actually in Tampa and also streamlining sort of our mechanical facilities and shops that are aligned more with our triangle in the core network that we have. Our job is to really become less resource intensive, so between train lengths and the sort of density of the train as well as the density of the route that we route the train has also allowed us significant savings across the board. So I think there's really no one thing. I think that we've accelerated that would really answer your question, but we are able -- as we're able to put initiatives in place, we are doing so and continually looking for more. We have great momentum here. Everyone is overdelivering. And I think technology's a big help for us. And also some of our working with the labor organization is also a big help for us.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you for that very detailed answer. And maybe as a follow-on, I understand that there's a fairly big initiative internally given that Intermodal is going to be a bigger part of the puzzle going forward to make Intermodal more consistently profitable
componenttext: Thank you for that very detailed answer. And maybe as a follow-on, I understand that there's a fairly big initiative internally given that Intermodal is going to be a bigger part of the puzzle going forward to make Intermodal more consistently profitable going forward. And it occurs to me that some of the initiatives to achieve that goal come from the marketing side. And I'm wondering if Fredrik can talk about some of the initiatives that perhaps sales and marketing has underway within the Intermodal to sort of normalize the volume so that you're running full trains everyday of the week, every week of the year, that's always an obviously very difficult amount of decline, but can you talk a little bit about what you're doing there, perhaps in working with third parties to fill all the trains up everyday to really leverage that productivity?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, there's a variety of things there that we are working on, right, John, and some of them are, I think, at this point, are ready for public consumption, some of them are not. But overall, you're absolutely right. In the environment where the RPU is so
componenttext: Yes, there's a variety of things there that we are working on, right, John, and some of them are, I think, at this point, are ready for public consumption, some of them are not. But overall, you're absolutely right. In the environment where the RPU is so much over, one of the key things that you can do to drive up margins is to make sure that you have a much more leveled workload, and the team is certainly working on that and thinking too how we can do that longer term. That is a pretty significant structural change. In the meantime, what we're trying to do is work on terminal productivity. We have a variety of initiatives in place there that has yielded a lot of results here. We continue to work on train lengths in the intermodal space to make sure, just as we do elsewhere in our business, to allow for the leverage that occurs there. Of course, double-stack clearance is as important. And you know where we are with the Virginia Avenue tunnel. By the end of this year, we should be able to double-stack clear there as well. And then the hub-and-spoke strategy that we've lined out for all of you for a long time has allowed for a significant amount of efficiency being able to penetrate some of these smaller markets with a lot more density that we otherwise could. And of course, overall speed of the network itself, which I alluded to before, which has been a priority as we think about the service improvements here in 2016, because the turn time on the equipment is critical. And then to your point, and this is a little bit, a little more longer term, how do you structurally ensure that the day of the week balancing is a little bit better than what it is today. But that is, I think, a little bit longer-term initiative from our perspective.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Bascome Majors of Susquehanna.
componenttext: The next question comes from Bascome Majors of Susquehanna.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: We talk a lot about rising competition and its impact on Intermodal. But I wanted to focus on how you take your car merchandise business. Do you have a sense of how much share loss the truck has been a drag on overall volumes? And I guess, more importantl
componenttext: We talk a lot about rising competition and its impact on Intermodal. But I wanted to focus on how you take your car merchandise business. Do you have a sense of how much share loss the truck has been a drag on overall volumes? And I guess, more importantly, when you begin to cycle the worse of that drag on what's called a year-over-year basis?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: One of the key things that we are focused on right now within our sales and marketing team is to sell through this cycle of excess capacity. And there is excess capacity in the truck market, and that is probably impacting our volume to some degree, but on
componenttext: One of the key things that we are focused on right now within our sales and marketing team is to sell through this cycle of excess capacity. And there is excess capacity in the truck market, and that is probably impacting our volume to some degree, but one of the key things for us is to continue to be able to reinvest in our business, and not necessarily chase that down too much when we see these temporary changes because we do have to be able to be there for our customers day in and day out. And that's one of the things that we sell with our customers, that we got to work through the downturn that we're seeing right now, and we want to be able to be there for you, not just today but also tomorrow when capacity is tighter. So we are seeing in certain other markets beyond Intermodal where there has been probably some share loss to truck. We look at that each and every deal as the marketplace, and we always try to estimate what the second-best alternative is and try to match that. And in certain places where that is, is below what we think is long-term reinvestable for us, at that point, we probably don't participate because we don’t want to do anything artificially. It's -- the pricing level is critical. With the service improvements that we've gotten here, we've been able to sustain and allow customer to see the long-term value that access to our network provides, but in certain places, we have seen some traffic go way back to truck.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And I just had a quick housekeeping one on one of your expense guidance items. On MS&O, it implies what you guided that we can be up as much as 10% sequentially from the second quarter in 3Q. Looking back, it's been 8 or 9 years since we've se
componenttext: Understood. And I just had a quick housekeeping one on one of your expense guidance items. On MS&O, it implies what you guided that we can be up as much as 10% sequentially from the second quarter in 3Q. Looking back, it's been 8 or 9 years since we've seen a magnitude of that rise from 2Q to 3Q. Can you guys give us a little color on what's driving that expectation of that big increase?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Frank. And not commenting on the numbers that you threw out there. As you know, MS&O is always difficult to predict in any given year, in any given quarter. I think what we said was that it will be down moderately versus the prior year, which does ha
componenttext: It's Frank. And not commenting on the numbers that you threw out there. As you know, MS&O is always difficult to predict in any given year, in any given quarter. I think what we said was that it will be down moderately versus the prior year, which does has some implications sequentially. I think what you're going to see is we had the timing item on the $10 million casualty reserves, so that's generally what we do in the second quarter. In the fourth quarter of each year, we relook at the probably and severity of casualty. And we had a favorable one-time item you shouldn't think about that on a sequential basis in the third quarter. And then in any given quarter, again, you have timing items and some small onetime items that are going to impact the sequential comparisons. So I think you're directionally accurate. Although again, not commenting on your numbers specifically.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Justin Long of Stephens.
componenttext: The next question comes from Justin Long of Stephens.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I wanted to start by asking about the point-to-point pricing initiative in coal. Could you provide an update on how far along you are in that process? And do you think this will be a tailwind or a headwind to the core price numbers you're putting out t
componenttext: So I wanted to start by asking about the point-to-point pricing initiative in coal. Could you provide an update on how far along you are in that process? And do you think this will be a tailwind or a headwind to the core price numbers you're putting out today?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we have implemented the point-to-point pricing across our coal network. And overall, I would say, the process has gone very well. The reason for doing that is to make sure we better match the true cost of service. Some of the locations that are further
componenttext: So we have implemented the point-to-point pricing across our coal network. And overall, I would say, the process has gone very well. The reason for doing that is to make sure we better match the true cost of service. Some of the locations that are further away from -- so-called our core routes to reflect the maintenance cost and operating cost that is associated with moving that. I don't think that, that will be material in any way, shape or form to our same-store sales measure. And that is really more about ensuring that as we try to rationalize the infrastructure in the coal fields that we, from a sales and marketing perspective, help operations to do that by truly reflecting what it costs to move some coal from certain of the mines that are further away from some of our core routes. That really all is about it. Not so much about the same-store sales changing because of it, even though I think, overall, I would say, probably it's slightly helpful.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Frederik, you put it in place on the tariffs, it will take some time to get through all the contracts [indiscernible].
componenttext: So Frederik, you put it in place on the tariffs, it will take some time to get through all the contracts [indiscernible].

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: That is correct as well. We put it in place in terms of the tariffs. We have adjusted 1 or 2 contracts, but it will probably take 1 or 2 or 3 years frankly to get it completely implemented across our whole book of business.
componenttext: That is correct as well. We put it in place in terms of the tariffs. We have adjusted 1 or 2 contracts, but it will probably take 1 or 2 or 3 years frankly to get it completely implemented across our whole book of business.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's helpful. And maybe as a quick follow-up. So the 4% increase in core price, excluding coal is a pretty strong number in this environment, it's also above what we've seen from some of the other rails year-to-date. Do you think this level of p
componenttext: Got it. That's helpful. And maybe as a quick follow-up. So the 4% increase in core price, excluding coal is a pretty strong number in this environment, it's also above what we've seen from some of the other rails year-to-date. Do you think this level of price increases is sustainable as we get into the back half of the year? Or is there risk we see some moderation given truckload capacity is pretty loose right now?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, so first of all, a great testament to those what our sales and marketing team has done in this tough environment, to your point about the strong results. And also clearly, a critical part of this has been the service improvements that we have seen.
componenttext: Well, so first of all, a great testament to those what our sales and marketing team has done in this tough environment, to your point about the strong results. And also clearly, a critical part of this has been the service improvements that we have seen. We don't really forecast what pricing will do over time. We will obviously disclose it each and every quarter in terms of our quarterly flash. But I think from our statements before, on one hand, we know value creation for CSX, pricing is a critical component of that, but I've also alluded to the fact that I think short term, meaning for the next 12 months or so, we see a period of excess capacity out there that certainly is impacting things. But overall, you have a chance to see it where it comes each and every quarter.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Don Broughton of Avondale Partners.
componenttext: The next question comes from Don Broughton of Avondale Partners.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Help me think about this strategically or help me understand how you think. I understand how that the strength of the U.S. dollar is affecting -- negatively affecting ag exports and exports of other commodities. I understand that why crude being under 70
componenttext: Help me think about this strategically or help me understand how you think. I understand how that the strength of the U.S. dollar is affecting -- negatively affecting ag exports and exports of other commodities. I understand that why crude being under 70 is affecting negatively chemical volume, and everything related to fracking and nat gas obviously under 4 is still -- is going to continue to be a headwind for coal. So what's your crystal ball -- not that your crystal ball is any better than anyone else's, but how do you -- you have to have a plan. What do you plan? Do you expect the dollar to stay strong, crude to stay above under 70, and nat gas to stay under 4 for the foreseeable future? Is that your expectation? Or are you planning for the dollar to get weaker the -- for crude to go back up and nat gas to go back up?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's where the flexibility, I think, in our resource planning is critical, because to your point earlier, there's a lot of crystal balls out there, but I'm not sure which crystal ball is better than the other. What we do, as I said earlier, we do go out
componenttext: That's where the flexibility, I think, in our resource planning is critical, because to your point earlier, there's a lot of crystal balls out there, but I'm not sure which crystal ball is better than the other. What we do, as I said earlier, we do go out to our customers in the fall to try to get a sense of what they're seeing in the different markers that we serve. And then from there, we take their best input and triangulate with other things to put together our perspective on 2017. And it is a very volatile marketplace right now where it's very hard to predict. We have laid out that, overall, from a coal perspective, we do think that there's a secular decline that we're heading towards. And certainly, we've seen the vast majority of that already. The U.S. dollar, it is impossible for me to sit here and predict what the U.S. dollar is probably much better to look at a forward curve than me speculating on that, but the key thing for us is that we continue to have flexibility in our resource planning. And right now, the best predictor of tomorrow is today. The dollar is strong, and the locomotive prices are there. So that's kind of how we approach this.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: What does your crystal ball say?
componenttext: What does your crystal ball say?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: My crystal ball says that crude is going to under 70, and nat gas is going to stay under 4 for the foreseeable future. And that there's nothing that indicate that the dollar is going to get weaker anytime soon. But again, whose crystal ball is better than
componenttext: My crystal ball says that crude is going to under 70, and nat gas is going to stay under 4 for the foreseeable future. And that there's nothing that indicate that the dollar is going to get weaker anytime soon. But again, whose crystal ball is better than the other? I just wondered what you're planning against -- what's your best guess. And because obviously, I understand what you're triangulating your expectations to your customers, but you have to have your own internal gauge as to where you're going as well.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and then I think that goes back to the point of flexibility. It is so hard to plan these days, and I think Cindy and team has done a fabulous job. They're really variablizing [ph] our cost structure. We talked that for a long time, and then we do wha
componenttext: Yes, and then I think that goes back to the point of flexibility. It is so hard to plan these days, and I think Cindy and team has done a fabulous job. They're really variablizing [ph] our cost structure. We talked that for a long time, and then we do whatever we can to forecast, and even on a monthly basis and try  to float it around the network, so we can make very timely changes to our network based on the best information we have, but it's hard to see much beyond 1 month to 3 months at this point.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from John Barnes of RBC Capital.
componenttext: The next question comes from John Barnes of RBC Capital.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two things. One, you indicated that you saw more spot load activity on coal volumes in the quarter. Frederik, I think you alluded to a few more phone calls. Do you have a sense for how much volume moved in the quarter was on the spot basis versus kind of
componenttext: Two things. One, you indicated that you saw more spot load activity on coal volumes in the quarter. Frederik, I think you alluded to a few more phone calls. Do you have a sense for how much volume moved in the quarter was on the spot basis versus kind of on a normal contractual basis?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the export side?
componenttext: On the export side?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Was there [indiscernible] Domestic.
componenttext: Was there [indiscernible] Domestic.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Or overall?
componenttext: Or overall?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Overall.
componenttext: Overall.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Overall. As you well know, on the export side, pretty much everything is spot these days. So also that's a great example of the previous question around things change very fast in terms of how much we move. And we did see a pickup on the export side in th
componenttext: Overall. As you well know, on the export side, pretty much everything is spot these days. So also that's a great example of the previous question around things change very fast in terms of how much we move. And we did see a pickup on the export side in the second quarter beyond what we have originally anticipated, which is why we increased the guidance on the export side to about 20 million tons for the year. On the domestic side, really, the cost that we've received is really coming here over the last, I would say, 3 to 4 weeks, and so we really haven't had a chance to move a lot of that yet. But we do expect a little bit of a sequential uptick on the domestic coal, which is embedded in the guidance as we expect export coal to be weaker in the second half, we expect the domestic coal to be slightly stronger within that $22 million to $23 million -- 22 million to 23 million tons for the quarter.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, all right. And then my second question, and this is a little bit longer term, more strategic in nature. I recognize both of these things have only occurred since kind of July 1, but you've got the expanded Panama Canal is now open, the pickings are
componenttext: Okay, all right. And then my second question, and this is a little bit longer term, more strategic in nature. I recognize both of these things have only occurred since kind of July 1, but you've got the expanded Panama Canal is now open, the pickings are pretty solid thus far, and then you have the SOLAS rules go into effect on July 1 as well. Have you seen any impact of either -- and what do you think are the longer-term impacts? I mean, what do you think it means, is there a stair step in volume oas a result of one or both? Or is it just moving -- is this just changing where the freight -- how the freight gets to you but no real stair step?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the SOLAS, first of all, we really haven't seen any impact at all, and we've spoken to our international customers, and it seems like the capabilities have been, they are either by the port or some of the other freight porters, or somebody else providi
componenttext: On the SOLAS, first of all, we really haven't seen any impact at all, and we've spoken to our international customers, and it seems like the capabilities have been, they are either by the port or some of the other freight porters, or somebody else providing that information as required. So we have not heard anything or we don't anticipate any impact on the international volumes because of SOLAS. In terms of Panama Canal, obviously, it is very recent. It is a little too early to tell. We have said this for a while that there are so many different drivers that comes into play here that it's very difficult to predict exactly what's going to happen. The good news is we have a flexible network. We will be able to handle additional volume coming into the East Coast if that happens. And we are working very closely, both on international customers and with the ports, to make sure we have the capability that we need if it is a bigger shift than we are currently anticipating.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Are the ports -- how far behind are the ports in being prepared for this? Is that [indiscernible]?
componenttext: Are the ports -- how far behind are the ports in being prepared for this? Is that [indiscernible]?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think it is my place to comment, John. I think, overall, we work very well with the ports. Some of the ports have better infrastructure than others, of course. But overall, it's a great relationship. And I think the East Coast ports are certainly
componenttext: I don't think it is my place to comment, John. I think, overall, we work very well with the ports. Some of the ports have better infrastructure than others, of course. But overall, it's a great relationship. And I think the East Coast ports are certainly seeing this as an opportunity, and have spent a fair amount of capital the last decade to prepare for this.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Keith Schoonmaker of MorningStar.
componenttext: The next question comes from Keith Schoonmaker of MorningStar.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is probably a question for Fredrik related to your last answer. Could you comment on the possibility that significant potential Panama Canal diversions from the historical land bridge route could be simply truckable when they arrive by ship?
componenttext: This is probably a question for Fredrik related to your last answer. Could you comment on the possibility that significant potential Panama Canal diversions from the historical land bridge route could be simply truckable when they arrive by ship?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so our view of this has been is that, as you -- if you do see a major shift over to the East Coast ports, what we will -- we might lose some traffic that goes into the coastal regions that will be trucked to those markets. However, we also see then t
componenttext: Yes, so our view of this has been is that, as you -- if you do see a major shift over to the East Coast ports, what we will -- we might lose some traffic that goes into the coastal regions that will be trucked to those markets. However, we also see then the opportunity to pick up some traffic into the Ohio Valley, into more kind of the southeast that is further away from the ports, including potentially also going all the way back up to Chicago. And we've seen a fair amount of shift already as the Suez Canal has taken up a bigger shift. We've seen as production in Asia has moved to -- more to the Southeast that we've seen additional volume coming into the ports. So we have the capability, but -- and there could be a little bit of a mix change. But overall, we feel that we're in a -- very well positioned to capture whatever happens.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks. And maybe just one more on truck competition. In the commentary, I think, that was issued last night, if I'm remembering correctly, there was a remark about forced products experiencing some competition from trucking, and yet you managed to
componenttext: Okay, thanks. And maybe just one more on truck competition. In the commentary, I think, that was issued last night, if I'm remembering correctly, there was a remark about forced products experiencing some competition from trucking, and yet you managed to grow domestic intermodal an impressive 5%. It's sort of a contrast there, losing in one area. Is this just pretty route-specific with the foreign streak?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, and the reason why the intermodal domestic has been as strong as it's been has been the fact that we onboarded a significant amount of new traffic from one specific customer last fall. And we are starting to lap the peers as we get to the third quar
componenttext: Well, and the reason why the intermodal domestic has been as strong as it's been has been the fact that we onboarded a significant amount of new traffic from one specific customer last fall. And we are starting to lap the peers as we get to the third quarter, hence, the guidance for not the same sort of growth and probably close to flat on the domestic side as we get to the third quarter. And obviously, long term, we think we can grow the domestic intermodal business kind of 5% to 10%, but we are in a period here on the domestic side and on the -- some of the merchandise side where we see some temporal weakness because of excess capacity, but we do fully expect that to be worked out over time and allow us to get back to more normalized growth rates as we move into, hopefully, the second half of the '17 or so.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: The last question comes from Scott Schneeberger of Oppenheimer.
componenttext: The last question comes from Scott Schneeberger of Oppenheimer.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm going to ask a couple of smaller segments since we're at the end here. But with regards to Middlesbrough, could you give us an update on what you're seeing there, and particularly, with steel? And is there a chance that it could swing to its positive
componenttext: I'm going to ask a couple of smaller segments since we're at the end here. But with regards to Middlesbrough, could you give us an update on what you're seeing there, and particularly, with steel? And is there a chance that it could swing to its positive volume growth within a matter of quarters?

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think steel production year-to-date is relatively flat year-over-year. And part of what has helped that has been that the countervailing tariffs and so forth has been very helpful to stem the flow of imports into the United States. Our volumes are down
componenttext: I think steel production year-to-date is relatively flat year-over-year. And part of what has helped that has been that the countervailing tariffs and so forth has been very helpful to stem the flow of imports into the United States. Our volumes are down a little bit more than that, and the reason for that is, on one hand, mill closures that has affected us specifically. We have 1 mill that we both have inbound and outbound too that has closed down. That was really a big driver for our volume decline. And we also are seeing impact in the metal side from a little bit more truck competition that we've seen before. And as we think about the second half, I think it's a little too early. I think we're going to have some of the specific CSX-related issues that is going to hurt us as we get into the second half of the year. So I think the second half will be pretty challenging still, but the key thing for us is to continue to work with our customers on the steel side, provide a better service product and continue to make sure we can reinvest in the business, and that's where we're focusing on.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the CSX Corporation Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] For opening remarks and introduction, I would like to turn the call over to
componenttext:
Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the CSX Corporation Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] 
For opening remarks and introduction, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. David Baggs, Vice President, Treasurer and Investor Relations Officer for CSX Corporation.

headline: CSX Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Prima, and good morning, everyone. And again, welcome to CSX Corporation's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Presentation.The presentation material that we'll be reviewing this morning, along with our quarterly financial report and our safety and
componenttext:
Thank you, Prima, and good morning, everyone. And again, welcome to CSX Corporation's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Presentation.
The presentation material that we'll be reviewing this morning, along with our quarterly financial report and our safety and service measurements, are available on our website at csx.com under the Investors section. 
In addition, following the presentation, the webcast replay will be available on that same website. 
This morning, our presentation will be led by Michael Ward, the company's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Frank Lonegro, our Chief Financial Officer. In addition, Cindy Sanborn, our Chief Operating Officer; and Fredrik Eliasson, our Chief Sales and Marketing Officer, will be available during the question-and-answer session.
Now before I turn the presentation over to Michael, let me remind everyone that the presentation and other statements made by the company contain forward-looking statements. You are encouraged to review the company's disclosure and the accompanying presentation on Slide 2.
