componenttext: Our next question comes from Allison Landry with Crédit Suisse.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Danny Schuster on for Allison. So last year, you had, on a net basis, a couple of pennies of onetime benefits. So I guess I was just trying to understand, if earnings are flat to slightly down in 4Q this year, does that imply that core earnings ar
componenttext: This is Danny Schuster on for Allison. So last year, you had, on a net basis, a couple of pennies of onetime benefits. So I guess I was just trying to understand, if earnings are flat to slightly down in 4Q this year, does that imply that core earnings are actually starting to grow? And should we see that trend accelerate with continued cost reductions, moderated coal volumes, export coal pricing over the next few quarters?

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Danny, it's Frank. We tried to give you some insight into Q4 on a reported -- against a reported basis, the flat to slightly down, to try to give you a sense of some normal seasonality in the business quarter-over-quarter as well as perhaps a little bit o
componenttext: Danny, it's Frank. We tried to give you some insight into Q4 on a reported -- against a reported basis, the flat to slightly down, to try to give you a sense of some normal seasonality in the business quarter-over-quarter as well as perhaps a little bit of conservatism around what the impacts of the hurricane are ultimately going to be. So we tried to give you some clarity there, and I think what you're going to continue to see us do, as Cindy mentioned, is continue to focus on a great service product and the productivity as well as strong pricing for the value of the service we provide. So the pieces will remain the same going forward. So I think we tried to give you some sense of where we'll end up in the quarter, and obviously, that gives you some implication for the year and thinking about next year as well.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Rob Salmon with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Rob Salmon with Deutsche Bank.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Frank, with your prior comments, you've alluded to incorporating some of the hurricane impact on the fourth quarter. Can you give us a sense of what's baked into the model? And then a side, related -- actually, a different question there, but we saw some
componenttext: Frank, with your prior comments, you've alluded to incorporating some of the hurricane impact on the fourth quarter. Can you give us a sense of what's baked into the model? And then a side, related -- actually, a different question there, but we saw some really nice improvement in the intermodal RPU last quarter. Could you talk about your pricing initiatives within that segment and how much of that improvement was kind of the lapping out of some of the shorter length of haul business?

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. So really, 3 parts there. I'll tackle the financial piece of the hurricane, kick it over to Cindy and let her talk about the hurricane impacts and then, obviously, Fredrik on the intermodal side. We're still early in the process of understanding th
componenttext: Right. So really, 3 parts there. I'll tackle the financial piece of the hurricane, kick it over to Cindy and let her talk about the hurricane impacts and then, obviously, Fredrik on the intermodal side. We're still early in the process of understanding the impact of the hurricane, Cindy we'll talk about where we are operationally. We do have something modeled in there, but it's really just an early estimate. Until we get everything back up and running and we do the tally, we really don't have a good number for you this morning. We'll be out in early November, and we'll certainly have all of the things tied out by then and give you a sense of the impact then. But let me let Cindy talk about the operational piece.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As far as Hurricane Matthew, I think, both from a preparation and recovery, our employees have done an outstanding job managing through a storm that was highly impactful in terms of the amount of territory that was affected. And so as of this morning
componenttext: Yes. As far as Hurricane Matthew, I think, both from a preparation and recovery, our employees have done an outstanding job managing through a storm that was highly impactful in terms of the amount of territory that was affected. And so as of this morning, we are open on our core route on I-95, albeit with the use of generators to provide power to our assets that require electricity, crossings and signaling systems with generators. And commercial power is still not back. We'll still be nursing those generators until we can get commercial power back. But opening that route is very, very important to us. It's part of our triangle of core operations. We do have yet still some branch lines that are out, so unable to serve those customers as of this point, but we see good equipment availability and energy around getting those routes restored as well. And I think our impacts are going to be -- some will be capital, some will be operating expense. And then within that operating expense, we'll see some cycle time impacts from the storm. But truthfully, I am extremely pleased with where we are considering where the hurricane affected us and how quickly we've been able to come back.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Cindy, on some of those secondary lines, the waters have not even peaked yet. So until it does, it's hard to even get in there and assess the damage, right?
componenttext: And Cindy, on some of those secondary lines, the waters have not even peaked yet. So until it does, it's hard to even get in there and assess the damage, right?

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Specifically, in and around Lumberton, North Carolina, we are still -- have our railroad under several feet of water and -- which are going to be days before those floodwaters recede. And obviously, it's the effect in the community as well. And resto
componenttext: Yes. Specifically, in and around Lumberton, North Carolina, we are still -- have our railroad under several feet of water and -- which are going to be days before those floodwaters recede. And obviously, it's the effect in the community as well. And restoring service in all these areas we feel like helps the communities recover as we bring in supply. So there's still quite a bit of work to do.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then in terms of intermodal question, we are continuing to get some price in intermodal, obviously not as much as we have in the past because of the excess capacity it's up in the marketplace that's offset by -- what we're seeing on the fuel side, but
componenttext: And then in terms of intermodal question, we are continuing to get some price in intermodal, obviously not as much as we have in the past because of the excess capacity it's up in the marketplace that's offset by -- what we're seeing on the fuel side, but we also seeing some positive mix in the portfolio. Part of that is some of the short-haul business that have shifted over. So overall, we're pretty pleased with the performance we've seen from RPU perspective intermodal business.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Ravi Shanker for Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Ravi Shanker for Morgan Stanley.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a follow up on the pricing question. your all in same-store pricing continue to remain about inflation, which is great. But it has been sequentially declining a little bit. So how do we think about that in the fourth quarter and beyond? I mean, what's
componenttext: So a follow up on the pricing question. your all in same-store pricing continue to remain about inflation, which is great. But it has been sequentially declining a little bit. So how do we think about that in the fourth quarter and beyond? I mean, what's the floor for that number? Is that this level, is it inflation? And thus, does the the bounds and export coal help you at all starting next quarter?

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So in terms of overall same-store pricing, we're obviously very transparent watch we're doing do every quarter you have an opportunity to see that in the fourth quarter. There is clearly a more difficult rate environment, and it's been there for a p
componenttext: Sure. So in terms of overall same-store pricing, we're obviously very transparent watch we're doing do every quarter you have an opportunity to see that in the fourth quarter. There is clearly a more difficult rate environment, and it's been there for a period of time as we've seen significant amount of excess capacity. Our focus continues to be to price the value that we provide that our customers to be able to continue to reinvest. We have an improved service product year-over-year that is very helpful. And what we're trying to do is to sell through this trough, so to speak and sell the kind of the long-term access to a network and the capacity that we have. Specific to export coal, I think we've been very transparent over the last couple of years that as the market has gone tougher since 2012, we have been taking our price is down to obviously optimize our own portfolio but also to help strategic to some of the producers. We do have the ability to touch those contracts on -- essentially quarterly basis or some of those are indexed. And so with the uptick and the benchmark that we've seen here, which obviously gives us an opportunity to leverage that uptick, which is good news.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Ken Hoexter from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: The next question comes from Ken Hoexter from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to talk, you mentioned to Tom earlier about increasing car length and maybe more investment, Cindy. Is there something you need to make more additional CapEx and spending on to be able to get even longer train length? Is that something that yo
componenttext: Just wanted to talk, you mentioned to Tom earlier about increasing car length and maybe more investment, Cindy. Is there something you need to make more additional CapEx and spending on to be able to get even longer train length? Is that something that you're starting to peak out or is still additional room for productivity improvement there?

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ken. So I would say that we do -- we are making investments. I've been talking last couple of quarters about our route from Nashville to Cincinnati that we were investing this year that, that would be in service as of the third quarter, so it is in s
componenttext: Yes, Ken. So I would say that we do -- we are making investments. I've been talking last couple of quarters about our route from Nashville to Cincinnati that we were investing this year that, that would be in service as of the third quarter, so it is in service, and we've seen some good improvement in length there. We were restricted to -- based on sitings to about 6500 feet on that corridor. So with that type of investment that we will continue.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll continue to do now.
componenttext: We'll continue to do now.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our coal there, about 12,000, 12,000 feet. So moving forward, we have identified several locations to continued those types of investments. But as you relieve the pressure on the quarter that we just did, then you now find that you're meeting up again som
componenttext: Our coal there, about 12,000, 12,000 feet. So moving forward, we have identified several locations to continued those types of investments. But as you relieve the pressure on the quarter that we just did, then you now find that you're meeting up again some other impacts on other corridor. So that's what we'll be looking and are looking in the process of assessing and or building to continue to improve the train length.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Ken, one of the things on the CapEx, what Cindy is referring to is absolutely what we're going forward, it's reallocation of capital within that longer-term guidance that we've spoken about previously. So as you go into 2017, the things that are strat
componenttext: And Ken, one of the things on the CapEx, what Cindy is referring to is absolutely what we're going forward, it's reallocation of capital within that longer-term guidance that we've spoken about previously. So as you go into 2017, the things that are strategically aligned in terms of the network of the tomorrow, highly automated railroad, service excellence, et cetera, those are going to be within the confines of the normal capital process. And as you size that next year, I wouldn't think of that is being incremental investment versus reallocated investment within that portfolio.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's really helpful, Frank. And Fred, a follow-up if I may, on coal, your thoughts and utility on where inventory levels are. This is really interesting just given -- I don't  know the extended heat that we have here. But is there stabilization going on
componenttext: That's really helpful, Frank. And Fred, a follow-up if I may, on coal, your thoughts and utility on where inventory levels are. This is really interesting just given -- I don't  know the extended heat that we have here. But is there stabilization going on at the domestic side and your thoughts we had an infection point perhaps where I don't the inventory levels have come down far enough or net gas pricing is high enough? You maybe just give us some thoughts on the domestic side.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So clearly the hot summer has been helpful, the cooling degree days as been very helpful especially in the South. We've seen significant reduction in the inventory levels I think in the south in terms of days burn. We're down from 150 a year ago to
componenttext: Sure. So clearly the hot summer has been helpful, the cooling degree days as been very helpful especially in the South. We've seen significant reduction in the inventory levels I think in the south in terms of days burn. We're down from 150 a year ago to somewhere around 100 now and even north, we've come down a little bit. I would say though overall that there are probably still slightly above where they would like for them to be. There are certain places that are less, certain places that are more, but probably still a little bit about where they would like it for them to be. But it is good news that we're starting to see that, and we all see point natural gas prices, they have come up a little bit. That's also helpful. Generally though, we do need to see those natural gas prices closer to 3 50 or above to make really meaningful impact. And we're excited where we're heading. We'll have a much better view, I think, as we'll get into the fourth quarter and early next year in terms of what coal will do for 2017, not just in the domestic side but also on the export side.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Brandon Oglenski with Barclays.
componenttext: Next question comes from Brandon Oglenski with Barclays.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: So when I look at these efficiency numbers, they're pretty big. [indiscernible] $300 million to $400 million in efficiency this year. That would equate, I don't know, may be greater than 3% on the operating ratio, the 300 points -- basis points that is. S
componenttext: So when I look at these efficiency numbers, they're pretty big. [indiscernible] $300 million to $400 million in efficiency this year. That would equate, I don't know, may be greater than 3% on the operating ratio, the 300 points -- basis points that is. So I mean is that the type of improvement that investors should be thinking about as we look into '17 and beyond? Can we start to see 100, 200 basis points improvement annually and the operating ratios efficiency target hold, and you get to a more stable or maybe a growth environment?

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think, as I said before, we have a pretty extraordinary year this year, which you're referring to which is part of our views on how our business mix has changed within less reliance upon coal. So there's some structural take out that we put in place
componenttext: So I think, as I said before, we have a pretty extraordinary year this year, which you're referring to which is part of our views on how our business mix has changed within less reliance upon coal. So there's some structural take out that we put in place that can't repeat because it is structural around the coal markets. But going forward, we have lapped for this year some of our train length initiatives, but I've mentioned in the last question, we see opportunities going forward. We see productivity available to us that we traditionally have around streamlining again around our core network, which is part of our network of tomorrow. But I think run rate-wise looking into 2017, it would be more of a $150 million offsetting inflation kind of number to place of after having such a strong year this year. But we don't stop thinking about ways to improve our efficiencies. We understand that as our business mix changes, we had to make our merchandise and intermodal service products more profitable. And the operating part has huge lever we have to pull on the cost side to make that happen. So we're going to continue to look for those opportunities and drive it forward. And I will say -- add to that, that we also are going to serve our customers effectively to provide a very good service for them that allows Fredrik to grow the business and price the business.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brandon, one of the thoughts is, in terms of your illusion to growth there as we grow especially if we grow in the class merchandise business and automotive and intermodal, I mean, you're going to see incremental margins that really full in the operating
componenttext: Brandon, one of the thoughts is, in terms of your illusion to growth there as we grow especially if we grow in the class merchandise business and automotive and intermodal, I mean, you're going to see incremental margins that really full in the operating leverage point. So in addition to the productivity line, you should see the benefit of that, again, if the economy is cooperative for us longer term.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I should add, we do see capability on that. We're adding growth in any pretty much any market without adding cost back one-for-one. So we do see great leverage there.
componenttext: Yes, I should add, we do see capability on that. We're adding growth in any pretty much any market without adding cost back one-for-one. So we do see great leverage there.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess, I don't want to be too critical here, but as far as you're doing offsetting inflation next year, let's say, on the productivity side. This is going to come up as critical, but how is the CSX of Tomorrow any different than grow to 65 by 2015
componenttext: Well, I guess, I don't want to be too critical here, but as far as you're doing offsetting inflation next year, let's say, on the productivity side. This is going to come up as critical, but how is the CSX of Tomorrow any different than grow to 65 by 2015, which we heard in 2011? It just sounds like it's going to be a struggle to get a lot of operating ratio improvement unless something changes on the demand side or am I thinking about that wrong?

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, I think there is no -- everything on the table has been as long as I've worked here, and we're continuing to make sure that there is -- any opportunity we have, we were going to take advantage of. So I think to your point, it may seem not as stron
componenttext: I mean, I think there is no -- everything on the table has been as long as I've worked here, and we're continuing to make sure that there is -- any opportunity we have, we were going to take advantage of. So I think to your point, it may seem not as strong as this year, but our objectives are to not just look at 2017 by itself, but also continuing into the future and drive operating margins on the cost side. And we're coming off a strong year. We think we can offset inflation next year, but we are not going to leave any opportunity out there on the cost side.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brandon, this is Michael. I mean, obviously, productivity is going to key in well as Cindy said, always trying to do more than what she's talking about. But growth does have to be a critical component as we move to mid-60s operating ratio. We've [indiscer
componenttext: Brandon, this is Michael. I mean, obviously, productivity is going to key in well as Cindy said, always trying to do more than what she's talking about. But growth does have to be a critical component as we move to mid-60s operating ratio. We've [indiscernible] the economy here for the last 2 years and clearly growth has to be part of that equation, and we think that the service products we have can grow once we see any signs of vibrancy in the economy, but that is part of the equation.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Brandon, we're confident in our ability to get into the mid-60s operating ratio. The timing of that is going to depend on the rate of decline in coal, obviously, but continuing to focus on value pricing for the service product that we brighter our cu
componenttext: Yes, Brandon, we're confident in our ability to get into the mid-60s operating ratio. The timing of that is going to depend on the rate of decline in coal, obviously, but continuing to focus on value pricing for the service product that we brighter our customers continuing to have productive offset inflation. I mean, you do get margin expansion by doing that year-over-year.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Brian Ossenbeck with JPMC.
componenttext: Next question comes from Brian Ossenbeck with JPMC.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question on the coal network and rationalizing that further obviously, you made some actions with Irwin and Corbin that you're going to lap here pretty soon into next year. So what are you looking at when it comes to being able to take the next ste
componenttext: Just a question on the coal network and rationalizing that further obviously, you made some actions with Irwin and Corbin that you're going to lap here pretty soon into next year. So what are you looking at when it comes to being able to take the next steps? Is it just coal volumes getting into a certain level, densities perhaps getting a little bit higher when you factor in some of the point-to-point pricing? So just kind of your thought process on how you -- what you think internally just on timing for some of these initiatives to keep moving in the coal field?

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we are going to serve our coal customers well, and that is -- Fredrik and I work in our teams work on that to make sure that we are available and capable of providing service to our coal customers. As things change within the coal fields, I
componenttext: Well, I think we are going to serve our coal customers well, and that is -- Fredrik and I work in our teams work on that to make sure that we are available and capable of providing service to our coal customers. As things change within the coal fields, I think even more than they already have, we will take the steps that we need to take to structurally change, along with those changes. So we're prepared to continue to look there, but it's a profitable business for us, and we intend to stay in that business where the customers are for as long as they're there.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Just Michael, one follow up on the growth that you mentioned. Port of Savannah was out maybe a couple of weeks ago now, announcing their large expansion of the rail terminal there. Looks like they're going to double capacity longer trains the facili
componenttext: Okay. Just Michael, one follow up on the growth that you mentioned. Port of Savannah was out maybe a couple of weeks ago now, announcing their large expansion of the rail terminal there. Looks like they're going to double capacity longer trains the facility. Is that volume starting to be spoken for attracting customers? Or do you really need to see the complete expansion sometime in 2020 before that really start to drive some more volume on your network?

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. This is Fredrik. What we're seeing and have been seeing is a continued shift towards more East Coast international intermodal coming in versus West Coast. And as a result, the ports are clearly making investment not just Savannah but other ports as
componenttext: Sure. This is Fredrik. What we're seeing and have been seeing is a continued shift towards more East Coast international intermodal coming in versus West Coast. And as a result, the ports are clearly making investment not just Savannah but other ports as well, and we are as well to make sure we can serve that and that is attractive business that we wanted to get more of. And as we see additional investment come online, we have an opportunity. In the Savannah case, we certainly have grown our business significant there already, and we expect to continue to see that going forward, but that is true for the other port as well.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Christian Wetherbee with Citigroup.
componenttext: Next question comes from Christian Wetherbee with Citigroup.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question is on CapEx. Just kind of wondering as we look at the year-to-date progress so far towards the $2.7 billion number, they're still a lot left to go here. I don't think you're kind of taking that $2.7 billion number down. I'm guessing that the l
componenttext: My question is on CapEx. Just kind of wondering as we look at the year-to-date progress so far towards the $2.7 billion number, they're still a lot left to go here. I don't think you're kind of taking that $2.7 billion number down. I'm guessing that the locomotive pull forward from 2017 might still be backend weighted, it might be part of that sort of $1 billion-plus that I think you're targeting for the fourth quarter. But just want to get a rough sense of maybe how we think about this number. And then maybe thinking a little bit longer term to a previous question, Frank, you said a sort of reallocation on where you're spending the capital. What is the right number to be thinking of that reallocated capital? Is it a percent of revenue, it an absolute number in the mid-$2 billion type of range? I just want to get a sense of how you think about that.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Hey, Chris. This is Frank. So on the $2.7 billion, that is what we call our managed capital number. As part of that, you'll have 2 things in there, you'll have the $300-or-so million that we pulled forward from the seller financing of next year into
componenttext: Sure. Hey, Chris. This is Frank. So on the $2.7 billion, that is what we call our managed capital number. As part of that, you'll have 2 things in there, you'll have the $300-or-so million that we pulled forward from the seller financing of next year into this year and paying off locomotives as delivered. The other piece, which will show up in other financing activities so not in the property additions line will be $300 million for paying off engines that we took delivery off last year. So your $2.7 billion is again we try to be very transparent with you in terms of the capital dollars that we're spending this year, although you do have some geography differences on the cash flow statement. In terms of 2017, when you think about where we are, we're looking very hard on infrastructure and equipment given the environment that we're in and given the network of tomorrow strategy that we have. What we've been talking about is normalize stay of 5- or 10-year view in retrospect for CapEx, we generally spend somewhere between 12% and 15% of that capital portfolio on return seeking investments. What we're looking forward to doing on a going-forward basis is to increase that allocation to more like 20% or 25% of the capital portfolio. So not looking to necessarily increase capital based on the strategy, we're really looking to reallocate to make sure that the focus on the things that are going to drive value in the future.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. I appreciate that color. And then the follow up just sort of context capital allocation across sort of the spectrum. When you think about next year, debt levels relative to share buybacks, how should we think about -- how does share
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. I appreciate that color. And then the follow up just sort of context capital allocation across sort of the spectrum. When you think about next year, debt levels relative to share buybacks, how should we think about -- how does share buyback and a play in into the long-term plan?

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. It's part of the balanced deployment of capital. Certainly, the primary focuses of capital is going to reinvest in the business for reliable railroad and accretive type investments. Secondarily, would be the dividend piece and obviously we're lookin
componenttext: Sure. It's part of the balanced deployment of capital. Certainly, the primary focuses of capital is going to reinvest in the business for reliable railroad and accretive type investments. Secondarily, would be the dividend piece and obviously we're looking hard at that since we took a break this year on the dividend, but we're going to look at the heart of that next year. And then looking at where we are on operating cash flow next year and sizing a buyback program that generally we talk to you about in the end of the first quarter of a given year. So I think order is important for the investors to keep in mind and realizing that the environment that we're in now is perhaps quite a bit different than the environment that we were in 2015 when we increased the dividend by $0.02 and announced the 2 year, $2 billion program that will complete by April of next year.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Bascome Majors with Susquehanna.
componenttext: The next question comes from Bascome Majors with Susquehanna.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Frank, I want to drill down on another answer on the margins and cost side. Given the cost take out that you've achieved over the last several quarters, it's been while since we've had a year where you went from a big revenue decline to potential return t
componenttext: Frank, I want to drill down on another answer on the margins and cost side. Given the cost take out that you've achieved over the last several quarters, it's been while since we've had a year where you went from a big revenue decline to potential return to growth. And your best incrementals of the recent years have been around 50% on the margin side. I'm just curious, I'm not necessarily saying that revenue will return next year, but when it does return, given the takeout you've done, what kind of incremental ball park are you thinking about in the business?

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: When you look at what we've done of the cost side, certainly that sets up incremental margins that are probably better than what they been historically. But as I alluded to in the answer to the earlier question, it really depends on how the business comes
componenttext: When you look at what we've done of the cost side, certainly that sets up incremental margins that are probably better than what they been historically. But as I alluded to in the answer to the earlier question, it really depends on how the business comes back. If it comes back in areas where you're adding a box car onto an existing train and an intermodal container on the existing train and auto wreck of an existing train, that's really where you're to get the government the margin operating leverage secure frankly. If it's something that's on the bulk side of the business, which is going to be a new train starts, the incremental margins are going to essentially be with the absolute margins are in that business, by and large. So I do think we've set ourselves up for a good run as the economy improves and as volumes comes back, especially on the class side of the business.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just a bit of a housekeeping on your cost guidance for 4Q. The MS&O guide, flat year-over-year. That's a signaling a pretty significant Q-over-Q growth, maybe 12% or so. I know you have the extra week, but that's maybe 10 points or so above the typica
componenttext: And just a bit of a housekeeping on your cost guidance for 4Q. The MS&O guide, flat year-over-year. That's a signaling a pretty significant Q-over-Q growth, maybe 12% or so. I know you have the extra week, but that's maybe 10 points or so above the typical sequential growth there. Can you just help us understand what's driving that besides -- above beyond the extra week?

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, there's a few things on the sequential side to think through given that we've got some incremental bulk business on the export side, the green side I n the automotive side, we've got additional engines in freight cars in the mix relative to the third
componenttext: Yes, there's a few things on the sequential side to think through given that we've got some incremental bulk business on the export side, the green side I n the automotive side, we've got additional engines in freight cars in the mix relative to the third quarter. So clearly, that's going to impact MS&O line on the materials and supply side. We are expecting normal seasonality in terms of normal winter. We didn't see necessarily as much of that last year, but we're expecting that this year just given what we understand the winter to hold. There's a normal seasonal shift between the third quarter and the fourth quarter as we stop the construction season as it gets too cold and too icy to work up north so we do have that. And then there's normally on the technology side on the hardware and software contracts come due, so we have that just in terms of seasonality. And then we're usually a little less fuel efficient as we get into the fourth quarter, and we're going to pull on everything as you've seen us do already this year. But as we set up a more normal fourth quarter, that's how we see it going. The other thing to think through is a lot of the hurricane side expenses to the extent that hit the OpEx line are going to hit here. So we got a little bit of a piece in there. And then when you look at the productivity as we've targeted about $400 million, it implies about a $60 million run rate for the quarter, and that's a little less than what we had seen in the third quarter. So you add all of that up and is going to be about flat on a year-on-year basis.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Scott Group with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: Next question comes from Scott Group with Wolfe Research.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to just go back to coal for a second. Fredrik, do you have the inventory levels for the north? And then on the net side, how quickly do the export rates reset higher? Can you just kind of frame what that opportunity is? And maybe how much of the ex
componenttext: Wanted to just go back to coal for a second. Fredrik, do you have the inventory levels for the north? And then on the net side, how quickly do the export rates reset higher? Can you just kind of frame what that opportunity is? And maybe how much of the export reach dropped over the past 5 years and kind of order of magnitude, how much do you think that they can rebound?

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. In terms of the inventory levels, we use PIRA data. So in the north, we went from about 95 days of burn. This time, last year, we're down to 90 now. And then in the South, 150 down to 102. So significant improvement. But as I said earlier, still abo
componenttext: Sure. In terms of the inventory levels, we use PIRA data. So in the north, we went from about 95 days of burn. This time, last year, we're down to 90 now. And then in the South, 150 down to 102. So significant improvement. But as I said earlier, still above what I would consider target level at this time of the year. Well this target has obviously changed a little bit more, it's more difficult these days because it depends a lot on where the utility is and the dispatch order, et cetera. To your question about met, obviously, it's come down significantly. i don't have a number of that I think we've shared before, but it is a significant adjustment and you've seen that play out in our RPU line since really 2012 and as we now sit here, and we've seen the benchmark go up to 200 from 92 50, I think it was in the third quarter, that is an opportunity for us to leverage. And our contracts has evolved over time to be essentially quarterly or based on an index that is tied to the benchmark.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just lastly, for Frank. I know we've got big incentive comp headwind in fourth quarter, third quarter. Should we be thinking about a similar large headwind in the first half of next year, too, or do we kind of moved to a more normalized inc
componenttext: Okay. And then just lastly, for Frank. I know we've got big incentive comp headwind in fourth quarter, third quarter. Should we be thinking about a similar large headwind in the first half of next year, too, or do we kind of moved to a more normalized incentive comp run rate on a year-over-year basis '17?

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, more normalized.
componenttext: Yes, more normalized.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Jason Seidl with Cowen.
componenttext: Next question comes from Jason Seidl with Cowen.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, I guess I'll piggyback a little bit on that coal question. When you talk about more normalized target levels, where would you put those target levels in both your southern and northern regions?
componenttext: I guess, I guess I'll piggyback a little bit on that coal question. When you talk about more normalized target levels, where would you put those target levels in both your southern and northern regions?

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as I've said, in the past, we have used a targeted days burn somewhere around 55 in the north, 70 I the South. However, I do think that it could be a little bit misleading these days because of the fact that utilities are situated very differently i
componenttext: Well, as I've said, in the past, we have used a targeted days burn somewhere around 55 in the north, 70 I the South. However, I do think that it could be a little bit misleading these days because of the fact that utilities are situated very differently in terms of where they are in the dispense order. It was easier to give those target levels in the past when you were the baseload. Now, it varies really by utility. But the good news is we've made significant inroads especially in the South, and we're getting closer to more normalized level and there are utilities, and we've seen this year over the last 3 months that clearly are below where they want to be, but we still have several utilities that are significantly above.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And when you look at sort of that 3 50 [indiscernible] you brought up of national gas, if we are well above that sort of considerable amount of time, what percent of the business you think -- of your coal business going to be positively affected by
componenttext: Okay. And when you look at sort of that 3 50 [indiscernible] you brought up of national gas, if we are well above that sort of considerable amount of time, what percent of the business you think -- of your coal business going to be positively affected by that?

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, if you look at where we are here this quarter, we have about 58% of our business either came from Illinois Basin or Powder River Basin. We saw a pretty significant shift towards Illinois Basin within that number. And we have said publicly that when i
componenttext: Yes, if you look at where we are here this quarter, we have about 58% of our business either came from Illinois Basin or Powder River Basin. We saw a pretty significant shift towards Illinois Basin within that number. And we have said publicly that when it is 3 50 or above, that part of our portfolio, so 58% of our portfolio is essentially in the money, and that will allow for significant increased utilization of those plants. And others a lot of other factors that plays into that. Clearly, where the plants are located makes a big difference. As you all know, that the natural gas prices of 3 50 is Henry Hub price. It is very different in certain parts of our service territory. But as a general rule, I still think that holds pretty well in terms of an indication over the plants that we serve become more competitive.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay that's where helpful. I guess, my follow up question will be on the pricing side. When you look at Intermodal merchandise to well above your cost inflation, but it did decelerate on a sequential basis. How are you thinking about sort of that competit
componenttext: Okay that's where helpful. I guess, my follow up question will be on the pricing side. When you look at Intermodal merchandise to well above your cost inflation, but it did decelerate on a sequential basis. How are you thinking about sort of that competitive market going forward? It looks like we've had a little bit of uptick on the spot side here with ELDs coming up. What are you guys looking for in '17 from that market?

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. It is clear that we had a tough market for an extended product of time now in terms of Texas capacity, and it does impact matches intermodal business but certain markets within a merchandise business as well. Generally, shorter haul, also generally
componenttext: Sure. It is clear that we had a tough market for an extended product of time now in terms of Texas capacity, and it does impact matches intermodal business but certain markets within a merchandise business as well. Generally, shorter haul, also generally lower contributory traffic that are most susceptible to being switched over to truck. As the market turns, and it will turn, we see new orders of truck -- of Class VIII  trucks have come down significantly, 30%, 40% year-over-year year-to-date. We know ELDs will be coming in by sometime in the second half of next year. And if the economy continues to expand and unemployment stays low, that should make to much better environment as we get into late '17 and that would be helpful. So our challenge on our team right now is to sell that improved service product that we have, sell-through this kind of trough and sell the long-term access to our networks that allow us to continue to reinvest in our business.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ben Hartford with Baird.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ben Hartford with Baird.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Cindy, could you talk about when you would anticipate a trough in the employee count? Is there any sort of visibility to that during the fourth quarter or in the early part of 2017?
componenttext: Cindy, could you talk about when you would anticipate a trough in the employee count? Is there any sort of visibility to that during the fourth quarter or in the early part of 2017?

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Frank. What we did was we guided to down slightly sequentially, but also put a bit of a qualifier on that one given the fact that we were probably done more than slightly sequentially from Q2 to Q3. So we're continuing to look across the board at all
componenttext: It's Frank. What we did was we guided to down slightly sequentially, but also put a bit of a qualifier on that one given the fact that we were probably done more than slightly sequentially from Q2 to Q3. So we're continuing to look across the board at all areas of resources, whether it's train and engine crews for folks and the rest of the operating department focus on the G&A side. I mean, what you've seen is across-the-board approach in terms of overall productivity as well as on the resource side and challenging the need for every dollar every vacancy when it comes up, we taking a look at it and making sure whether or not we need to feel that because I think you're going to see us focus, although the magnitude of the decreases in a year-over-year basis are obviously going to get smaller and smaller as we go forward. But you continue to see us look very hard at resources. Cindy, you have anything to add?

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't have.
componenttext: I don't have.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good. And then, Fredrik, if I could as more conceptual volume of the volume side. Volumes over the past 10 or 15 years have been flattish to even down, obviously, coal -- the coal headwinds have been noted. So as we look forward, the economic environment
componenttext: Good. And then, Fredrik, if I could as more conceptual volume of the volume side. Volumes over the past 10 or 15 years have been flattish to even down, obviously, coal -- the coal headwinds have been noted. So as we look forward, the economic environment being uncertain, if we use industrial production growth as a guide, do you have confidence or any sort of visibility to volume growth more closely approximating even whatever U.S. IP growth ends up being as coal -- as we transition away from coal given the volume growth opportunities longer term on the Intermodal side? Or is that 10- to 15-year trend kind of flattish volumes in the business, is that still a pretty appropriate bogey to think about over the next 3 to 5 years?

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, absolutely. I think that if you look at the long period of time, if you take out the coal, business you just look at the correlation between IDP and our merchandise business, it has correlated pretty well with it, probably just slightly unde
componenttext: Yes. I think, absolutely. I think that if you look at the long period of time, if you take out the coal, business you just look at the correlation between IDP and our merchandise business, it has correlated pretty well with it, probably just slightly underperformed IDP over an extended period of time, several decades. As I think about 2017 right now and obviously we are in the middle of our planning season and getting a lot of feedback for our customers, if you take out our coal business and also the crude-by-rail business, which is energy related, if you take that out and then we look at the rest of the portfolio, our merchandise and our intermodal business, we feel pretty good about what the portfolio can do here after very tough period of time and that we have pretty good confidence that based on the economic indicators we're seeing right now, based on the feedback from the customer, that we can return to more normalized growth environment next year in a nonenergy businesses. We will have it much better sense of the energy businesses as we get to the fourth quarter. But we are encouraged by what we're seeing in terms of our initial planning assumptions right now.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Cherilyn Radbourne with TD Securities.
componenttext: Next question comes from Cherilyn Radbourne with TD Securities.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: One of the things that really stood up in the quarter for me was just the year-over-year improvement in labor efficiency just given the volume decline that you were facing. Just wondering if you can give us some practical examples of how you're continuing
componenttext: One of the things that really stood up in the quarter for me was just the year-over-year improvement in labor efficiency just given the volume decline that you were facing. Just wondering if you can give us some practical examples of how you're continuing to generate that labor productivity.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Cherilyn, thanks. I think one of the better examples would be our longer train initiatives. They're looking at density of trains and being able to operate the same number of cars and fewer chunks. I think we're also were utilizing technology to help
componenttext: Yes, Cherilyn, thanks. I think one of the better examples would be our longer train initiatives. They're looking at density of trains and being able to operate the same number of cars and fewer chunks. I think we're also were utilizing technology to help us as well in being able to automate processes. So those are probably 2 of the bigger examples I can give you.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then Cherilyn, just in terms of raw orders of magnitude, the 3,900-or-so positions that we were down year-over-year, the majority of those and this is both efficiency side as well as the variables side, out of the train and engine mechanic and the up
componenttext: And then Cherilyn, just in terms of raw orders of magnitude, the 3,900-or-so positions that we were down year-over-year, the majority of those and this is both efficiency side as well as the variables side, out of the train and engine mechanic and the up support side of the business, but engining Intermodal G&A also down year-over-year. I mean, we are down across the board in terms of resources on a year-over-year basis and I think you're going to continue with perhaps the exception of technology as we really go into the highly automated railroad part of our strategy I mean, pretty much every group is trying to be as lean as they can.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from David Vernon with Bernstein.
componenttext: The next question comes from David Vernon with Bernstein.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: This has obviously been the big part of the story this year. As we think about next year and the growth being a little bit more in the schedule of network businesses, around merchandising and Intermodal, should we thinking that the incremental falter in t
componenttext: This has obviously been the big part of the story this year. As we think about next year and the growth being a little bit more in the schedule of network businesses, around merchandising and Intermodal, should we thinking that the incremental falter in that business could actually be a little bit better than maybe we've seen the incremental margins on average run in the past?

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think with expenses that we've taken out in the scheduled network sort of the across the board, that obviously sets us up for incremental margins that are healthy and perhaps a little bit better than they have been in the past. So yes is the answer
componenttext: Yes, I think with expenses that we've taken out in the scheduled network sort of the across the board, that obviously sets us up for incremental margins that are healthy and perhaps a little bit better than they have been in the past. So yes is the answer to your question.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Excellent. And then maybe just kind of -- if we kind of business couple of years let's see if we're kind of flat volume, obviously, the productivity has been a big part of it but how should we be thinking about these sort of organic earnings potential in
componenttext: Excellent. And then maybe just kind of -- if we kind of business couple of years let's see if we're kind of flat volume, obviously, the productivity has been a big part of it but how should we be thinking about these sort of organic earnings potential in the business over the next couple of years? I mean, is it possible to continue to pull our cost and grow for a few years everything is going to be a little bit more kind of the holding the line just kind of a flat growth environment?

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think if you're flat on volume and don't have any mixed impacts associated with it, it's really going to be what we've been able to do in the past, which is to -- we'll continue to offset inflation would productivity, we'll continue to have value
componenttext: Well, I think if you're flat on volume and don't have any mixed impacts associated with it, it's really going to be what we've been able to do in the past, which is to -- we'll continue to offset inflation would productivity, we'll continue to have value pricing that will fall to the bottom line and the combination of those two things will provide margin expansion a year-over-year basis in the environment that you mentioned.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it's actually expect sustainable earnings power even a little even if we're in a flat volume environment?
componenttext: So it's actually expect sustainable earnings power even a little even if we're in a flat volume environment?

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct.
componenttext: Correct.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Scott Schneeberger with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: The next question comes from Scott Schneeberger with Oppenheimer.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Automotive remains an area of strength for you. Just curious, how sustainable do you think it is just from an end market perspective? And also you cite new business ramp ups in the slide deck. What type of contributions should we think about over the comi
componenttext: Automotive remains an area of strength for you. Just curious, how sustainable do you think it is just from an end market perspective? And also you cite new business ramp ups in the slide deck. What type of contributions should we think about over the coming quarters there?

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So obviously, auto has been at a pretty high level here this year in terms of production, I think the latest estimate that we've seen is about 17 9. In terms of production, we're more closely tied to production sales. And next year, the latest estim
componenttext: Sure. So obviously, auto has been at a pretty high level here this year in terms of production, I think the latest estimate that we've seen is about 17 9. In terms of production, we're more closely tied to production sales. And next year, the latest estimate I have is a slight increase to about 18 million vehicles, and so that's helpful. We have on boarded some new customers this year that has helped and their contribution to the traffic is very attractive. And it is -- has been great journey for the automotive market overall coming out of recession, but it is probably fair to say that at the moment, it looks like we're hitting that high water mark, so to speak. We don't see coming down significantly from that. We think we're going to be more in line with what we're currently seeing. But obviously, we're being nimble there as well and to adjust the resource level, whether it's up or down, but right now, the best estimate is relatively flat environment for 2017.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just following up on the efficiency savings that we can infer here that you're looking for may be a base level of 150 as we look out into '17. As we look at our models and think about kind of the cadence through next year, is there anythin
componenttext: Great. And then just following up on the efficiency savings that we can infer here that you're looking for may be a base level of 150 as we look out into '17. As we look at our models and think about kind of the cadence through next year, is there anything special to keep in mind on that front? Or is just a progressive built?

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't think there's anything specific that would cause you to want to put different values in for the different quarters. It will be pretty much across the board even.
componenttext: Yes, I don't think there's anything specific that would cause you to want to put different values in for the different quarters. It will be pretty much across the board even.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Justin Long with Stephens.
componenttext: The next question comes from Justin Long with Stephens.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: So my first question was on coal. There are a lot of people that believe industry coal volumes will be up next year. I know you said 4Q weather will be important in terms of how things play out in 2017. But just assuming normal weather patterns, do you ha
componenttext: So my first question was on coal. There are a lot of people that believe industry coal volumes will be up next year. I know you said 4Q weather will be important in terms of how things play out in 2017. But just assuming normal weather patterns, do you have any high-level directional thoughts on how your coal volumes could trend next year?

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess, the only directional comment that I would say is it that it looks like by the end of this year, over a 5-year period, we will have lost about $2 billion of coal revenue and this year alone probably, an excess of $0.5 billion. So based on wh
componenttext: Well, I guess, the only directional comment that I would say is it that it looks like by the end of this year, over a 5-year period, we will have lost about $2 billion of coal revenue and this year alone probably, an excess of $0.5 billion. So based on what you're seeing right now, we think next year's decline will be significantly less than that. But beyond that, I really do think I want to stick with what I said earlier, which is that we'll have an update for you when we do the fourth quarter earnings call, both on the domestic side and on the export side because I think will be in a much better position because we are on the process of gathering our information from the utilities, the 40 to 50 utilities that we serve and I think that's the best way to give your guidance is to take the input that we get from them so that it's a lot more accurate than trying to speculate at this point.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. But you seem to imply with your commentary that directionally, you think that will be down next year, you're just not willing at this point to quantify that.
componenttext: Got it. But you seem to imply with your commentary that directionally, you think that will be down next year, you're just not willing at this point to quantify that.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's probably directional. What I'm trying to say. I think, clearly, the fact that natural gas prices has come up is helpful is still not 3 50. Inventory levels are still above what they should be. And we only have about 1 million tons or s
componenttext: Yes, I think that's probably directional. What I'm trying to say. I think, clearly, the fact that natural gas prices has come up is helpful is still not 3 50. Inventory levels are still above what they should be. And we only have about 1 million tons or so that probably come out next in terms of plant closure so that number is getting a lot smaller. But nevertheless, I think as we look at the crystal ball right now, that is probably as a place to be. But I say said, a cold winter natural gas prices move up above that 3 50 mark and that picture can change very rapidly.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's really helpful. And one quick follow up I wanted to ask on pricing. Fredrik, I believe you said you were still getting price in intermodal. But could you say if your intermodal pricing is above inflation? Or given the truck competition we're seeing
componenttext: That's really helpful. And one quick follow up I wanted to ask on pricing. Fredrik, I believe you said you were still getting price in intermodal. But could you say if your intermodal pricing is above inflation? Or given the truck competition we're seeing, are we seeing below inflation price increases in that intermodal business?

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've historically given you the breakdown of the 2 categories that we have, merchandise and intermodal, combined and all in. I think we'll stay at that level. Pricing is a critical part for us in order to continue to reinvest in the business and especial
componenttext: We've historically given you the breakdown of the 2 categories that we have, merchandise and intermodal, combined and all in. I think we'll stay at that level. Pricing is a critical part for us in order to continue to reinvest in the business and especially in intermodal as we put so much of our incremental capital towards intermodal. So being able to have the traffic at contributory levels, continue to push prices is a critical part of the strategy, and we are getting positive price exactly where it is. I think we'll keep those buckets that we have in place today.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Walter Spracklin with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: The next question comes from Walter Spracklin with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Samuel stepping in for Walter Spracklin. Just circling back, you mentioned how your East Coast volumes are seeing a bit of a bump. I'm just wondering how much of the volume bump is coming to the Panama Canal. And are you seeing shifting pumping pa
componenttext: This is Samuel stepping in for Walter Spracklin. Just circling back, you mentioned how your East Coast volumes are seeing a bit of a bump. I'm just wondering how much of the volume bump is coming to the Panama Canal. And are you seeing shifting pumping patterns there? How should we think about the impact moving forward?

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So this is Fredrik, again. We have seen this shift for an extended period of time that we see more of an international cargo coming in on the East Coast ports. We have not seen a significant change in the amount of volume coming in since the Panama
componenttext: Sure. So this is Fredrik, again. We have seen this shift for an extended period of time that we see more of an international cargo coming in on the East Coast ports. We have not seen a significant change in the amount of volume coming in since the Panama Canal got widened. What we are seeing that there are some bigger vessels coming in. But generally, it is not necessarily add capacity they're reconfiguring the strength that fewer vessels, and we're also seeing some realignment with vessels that before came to this Suez Canal that is now coming through the Panama Canal instead. But we are -- so there is not significant change, but the pattern has been there for a long time and we do expect pattern to continue that we will be more and more of a volume come through the East Coast ports.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our final question comes from Brian Connex bird with Vertical Research Partners.
componenttext: Our final question comes from Brian Connex bird with Vertical Research Partners.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: You guys covered quite a bit of ground. Just a question on inflation, it sounds just from the commentary in regards to efficiency, and still expected to remain pretty muted next year in the realm of 1.5%? But just looking at the labor increment those are
componenttext: You guys covered quite a bit of ground. Just a question on inflation, it sounds just from the commentary in regards to efficiency, and still expected to remain pretty muted next year in the realm of 1.5%? But just looking at the labor increment those are talking about for Q4, it's running around 4% probably includes a little bit extra from the extra week and just metal prices have been strong, maybe [indiscernible] up a little bit now. But is the expectation we're so going to be living in a pretty muted environment into '17 despite some of the indicators, say could be a little bit higher?

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think on the inflation side we have been on our muted environment year over the last couple of years. When you start thinking about the inflation more broadly as well as GDP and IDP potentially going up, there could be a little bit of pressure on the up
componenttext: I think on the inflation side we have been on our muted environment year over the last couple of years. When you start thinking about the inflation more broadly as well as GDP and IDP potentially going up, there could be a little bit of pressure on the upside. There is a little bit of the was in the second half of the year for labor in pension inflation that you're picking up, on which is, which accruals the game of starting in the middle of the year. Said there's that in there rather that in a sort of the core inflation run rate that's out there. But I think what you're hearing from us is regardless of what inflation is, we're going to do our level best to more than offset that with productivity. So I think having something in that 1 50, 1 75 range for inflation next year is probably a good start in place, and we offset that with productivity.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just of follow up one real quick one. Just intermodal the expectation that, I guess, pricing does funnel a little bit later next year has supply in tracking comes down the of these going to place. That's the -- is that assumption -- does it require improv
componenttext: Just of follow up one real quick one. Just intermodal the expectation that, I guess, pricing does funnel a little bit later next year has supply in tracking comes down the of these going to place. That's the -- is that assumption -- does it require improving demand for you to see improving pricing in that business? Or if we were go ahead and kind of where we stand today, does that make it a bit more challenging?

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it really supply and demand picture. See if you have ELDs and other regulatory constraints put pressure on the supply side, clearly additional growth in economy is also helpful. And if you remove 1 or 2 of those, it's going to prolong the per
componenttext: Yes, I think it really supply and demand picture. See if you have ELDs and other regulatory constraints put pressure on the supply side, clearly additional growth in economy is also helpful. And if you remove 1 or 2 of those, it's going to prolong the period where we see this excess capacity. So obviously, falling very closely and hoping for an economy that picks up more than we currently expect, that could be very helpful both in terms of our volume initiatives but also in terms of pricing.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. See all next month, next quarter. Thank you.
componenttext: Thank you. See all next month, next quarter. Thank you.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the CSX Corporation Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] For opening remarks and introduction, I'd like to turn the call over to Mr. D
componenttext:
Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the CSX Corporation Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] 
For opening remarks and introduction, I'd like to turn the call over to Mr. David Baggs, Vice President, Treasurer and Investor Relations Officer for CSX Corporation.

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Shirley, and good morning, everyone. And again, welcome to CSX Corporation's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Presentation. The presentation material that we'll review this morning, along with our expanded quarterly financial report and our safety a
componenttext:
Thank you, Shirley, and good morning, everyone. And again, welcome to CSX Corporation's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Presentation. The presentation material that we'll review this morning, along with our expanded quarterly financial report and our safety and service measurements, are available on our website at csx.com under the Investors section. In addition, following the presentation, the webcast replay will be available on that same website. 
This morning, our presentation will be led by Michael Ward, the company's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Frank Lonegro, our Chief Financial Officer. In addition, Cindy Sanborn, our Chief Operating Officer; and Fredrik Eliasson, our Chief Sales and Marketing Officer, will be available during the question-and-answer session. 
Now before I turn the presentation over to Michael, let me remind everyone that the presentation and other statements made by the company contain forward-looking statements. You are encouraged to review the company's disclosure in the accompanying presentation on Slide 2. This disclosure identifies forward-looking statements as well as the uncertainties and risks that could cause actual performance to differ materially from the results anticipated by these statements. In addition, at the end of the presentation, we will conduct a question-and-answer session with the research analysts. [Operator Instructions] 
And with that, let me turn the presentation over to CSX Corporation's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Michael Ward. Michael?

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, David. Good morning, everyone. Yesterday, CSX reported third quarter earnings per share of $0.48 compared to $0.52 per share in the same period last year. Revenue declined 8% in the quarter, consistent with an overall volume decline of 8%, whic
componenttext:
Thank you, David. Good morning, everyone. Yesterday, CSX reported third quarter earnings per share of $0.48 compared to $0.52 per share in the same period last year. Revenue declined 8% in the quarter, consistent with an overall volume decline of 8%, which included a 21% decline in coal volume. 
Turning to operations. Safety performance remained strong, and service levels continued to meet or exceed customer expectations, driving further network efficiency improvements. In addition, CSX further reduced structural costs in the quarter and aligned resources levels to lower volume while retaining the ability to flex those resources with demand. Continuing to match resources to demand, combined with our ongoing initiatives to support network fluidity, form the foundation to maximize future merchandise and intermodal growth opportunities. As significant cost savings partially offset the impact of lower volume and a changing business mix, operating income declined $92 million year-over-year to $841 million. At the same time, the operating ratio increased 70 basis points year-over-year to 69.0%. 
Before I hand the presentation over to Frank, let me thank our employees, customer and suppliers for their skillful planning and tireless efforts working together to manage the effects of Hurricane Matthew over the weekend and through this week. Times like this remind us of the paramount importance of safety for our employees, customers and the communities we serve as well as the critical importance of the service we provide for American businesses. 
Now I'll turn the presentation over to Frank, who will take us through the third quarter results and fourth quarter outlook in more detail. Frank?

headline: CSX Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michael, and good morning, everyone. Let me begin by providing more detail on our third quarter results. As Michael mentioned, revenue was down 8% or $229 million versus the prior year, driven primarily by lower volumes. Total volume decreased
componenttext:
Thank you, Michael, and good morning, everyone. Let me begin by providing more detail on our third quarter results. As Michael mentioned, revenue was down 8% or $229 million versus the prior year, driven primarily by lower volumes. Total volume decreased 8%, which impacted revenue by about $220 million. In addition, fuel recoveries declined $63 million in the quarter but was offset by strong core pricing from an improved service product. Thanks to our sales, pricing for the third quarter was up 2.3% overall and 3.6% excluding coal. 
Other revenue decreased $9 million, driven mainly by lower incidental charges versus the prior year.  Expenses decreased 7% versus the prior year, driven mainly by $112 million in efficiency gains and $53 million in lower volume-related costs. Operating income was $841 million in the third quarter, down 10% from last year. 
Looking below the line. Interest expense was up slightly from last year, with higher debt levels partially offset by lower rates, while other income increased $11 million. And finally, income taxes were $260 million in the quarter, with an effective tax rate of about 36%. Overall, net earnings were $455 million, down 10% versus the prior year, and EPS was $0.48 per share, down 8% versus last year. 
Now let me turn to the market outlook for the fourth quarter. Looking forward, you will notice that the outlook reflects our adjusted market alignments. As released in our third quarter earnings, we are now referring to our markets as shown on this slide, which is consistent with how we are managing the business. The previous food and consumer market is now part of agricultural and food products. Waste and the fly ash business have moved to chemicals, and the equipment business now resides in the renamed metals and equipment market. Reclass volume, revenue and RPU information for the last 3 years are available on our Investor Relations web page. 
In 2016, CSX' fiscal calendar includes a 53rd week, and as such, we will be reporting a 14-week fourth quarter. When talking -- excuse me, when taking the full quarter into account, with an extra week versus the same period last year, we expect volume to be roughly flat. However, on a 13-week comparable quarter basis, we continue to see a soft but stabilizing industrial economy with volume down year-over-year. In addition to the standard view we provide each quarter, which, on the slide, shows expectations for the 13-week comparable period, we have included a red, yellow, green designation to the far right, which shows the full quarter impact of the extra week on volume expectations. With that said, the market comments that follow reflect expectations on a 13-week comparable basis. 
Automotive is again expected to grow as light vehicle production remains strong and new business continues to ramp up. Agricultural and food products is expected to be neutral. The record grain harvest will drive year-over-year gains. However, market dynamics for ethanol remain challenged near term for CSX due to increased movements in storage in the Gulf region.  Export coal is also neutral as we are seeing some near-term increase in metallurgical demand, driven by reduced Chinese supplies, such that volume should be similar to last year's levels.
